Introduction

Be warned: This is a dense technical analysis of scales and modes. If you don‚Äôt have a solid grasp of music theory, the charts may look pretty, but much of my analysis may fly straight over your head. If you want to learn music theory, I have introductions to rhythm and harmony that provide much better starting points.

(Before we proceed: As always, please contact me ⟨aaronfreed.github.io/aboutme.html⟩ if you notice any errors or omissions.)

This page started as an analysis of the familiar Ionian (diatonic major) scale, its seven modes, and their interrelationships. You know the one. Whole step, whole step, half-step, whole step, whole step, whole step, half-step. Play the white keys on the piano from C to C. Doe, a deer, a female deer. There‚Äôs your Ionian scale.

What began this analysis was discovering that raising or lowering specific pat­terns of notes in the scale, one by one, produces a cycle that encompasses not merely all seven modes of the scale, but all eighty-four possible sets of Ionian modes and root notes, in a manner inextricably linked to the circle of fifths. That‚Äôs where it began, at least; I may never manage to climb back out of this rabbit hole again.

A brief (lol, lmao) explanation is perhaps in order. Of the seven modes that are ¬ß2 and ¬ß3‚Äôs central focus, six move varying numbers of the Ionian scale‚Äôs intervals either from the end to the beginning, or vice versa. (Ionian itself is the first mode.) These modes are usually numbered by their roots - i.e., which degree (note of the parent scale) they start on. Following this numbering, I‚Äôll list the C Ionian scale‚Äôs seven modes.

  • I use thin, blue, lowercase letters for minor or diminished intervals a semitone below Ionian.
  • I use a bold, orange, uppercase letter for the augmented interval a semitone above Ionian.
    • Augmented fourths and diminished fifths are both tritones; they just use different notations.
  • Scale links go to Ian Ring‚Äôs Scale Finder, an absolutely invaluable resource for scale analysis. I‚Äôm probably duplicating a lot of its analysis, although I suspect I‚Äôm coming at it from a slightly different angle.
The Seven Modes of the C Major Scale
# Mode 12 3 4 5 6 7 Comment
1Ionian C D E F G A BThe traditional major scale.
2Dorian D Ef G A Bc
3Phrygian Efg A Bcd
4Lydian F G AB C D EThe only mode that raises a note from Ionian.
5MixolydianG A B C D Ef
6Aeolian A Bc D EfgThe natural minor scale.
7Locrian Bcd EfgaRare due to its diminished root chord; many pieces that use it modulate out of it at times, creating a sense that we‚Äôre rarely truly ‚Äòhome‚Äô. It‚Äôs more eerie or mysterious than unsettling, though; the Ionian scale is too melodic for the latter, diminished root or not.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

These are just examples; it could also be something much better

Immediately recognizable examples of each mode include:

  • Ionian: The major scale is so ubiquitous I almost feel naming examples would insult readers‚Äô intelligence, but I have to give special mention to one for its historical importance as a pedagogical tool:
    • Richard Rodgers & Oscar Hammerstein II ‚Äì ‚ÄúDo-Re-Mi‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/drnBMAEA3AM⟩ (The Sound of Music, 1959) is in B‚ô≠ Ionian. If this isn‚Äôt how you learned solfège, I‚Äôll eat my hat. (Note: I am not currently wearing a hat.) In fact, you can probably recall this song‚Äôs melody to give yourself a vague idea how the first four modes sound:
      • Do = Ionian
      • Re = Dorian
      • Mi = Phrygian
      • Fa = Lydian
      (The lines for ‚ÄúSo‚Äù, ‚ÄúLa‚Äù, and ‚ÄúTi‚Äù reuse Ionian, Dorian, and Phrygian respectively.)
  • Dorian:
    • Michael Jackson‚Äôs ‚ÄúThriller‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/sOnqjkJTMaA⟩ (Thriller, 1982) is in C‚ôØ Dorian.
    • Tears for Fears‚Äô ‚ÄúMad World‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/u1ZvPSpLxCg⟩ (The Hurting, 1983) is in F‚ôØ Dorian.
      • Gary Jules‚Äô cover ⟨youtu.be/18YvjD9oH38⟩, originally from Trading Snakeoil for Wolftickets (2001) but best known for its use in Donnie Darko (2002), lowers it to F Dorian.
    • Daft Punk ft. Pharrell Williams‚Äô ‚ÄúGet Lucky‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/5NV6Rdv1a3I⟩ (Random Access Memories, 2013) is in B Dorian.
  • Phrygian:
    • Miles Davis & Gil Evans’ ‚ÄúSolea‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/fe8XfcClcB4⟩ (Sketches of Spain, 1960) is in D Phrygian.
    • Jefferson Airplane‚Äôs ‚ÄúWhite Rabbit‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/pnJM_jC7j_4⟩ (Surrealistic Pillow, 1967) is in F‚ôØ Phrygian. Notably, this was directly inspired by Sketches of Spain, though sources have disagreed on whether ‚ÄúSolea‚Äù or ‚ÄúConcierto de Aranjuez (Adagio)‚Äù was the specific inspiration.
    • Metallica‚Äôs ‚ÄúWherever I May Roam‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/Z-cEyiM9adE⟩ (Metallica, 1991) is in E Phrygian.
  • Lydian:
    • Rush‚Äôs ‚ÄúFreewill‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/urBpdyFCZmo⟩ (Permanent Waves, 1980) is mostly in F Lydian (its chorus is in D Ionian).
    • The Police‚Äôs ‚ÄúEvery Little Thing She Does Is Magic‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/aENX1Sf3fgQ⟩ (Ghost in the Machine, 1981) has verses in G Lydian.
    • Kōji Kondō‚Äôs ‚ÄúSaria‚Äôs Song‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/nxUOYKTqirk⟩ (The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, 1998) is in F Lydian. Arguably, the Lost Woods theme as a whole ⟨youtu.be/naaYxXHNyl0⟩ is mostly in C Ionian, but ‚ÄúSaria‚Äôs Song‚Äù specifically refers to the six-note ocarina melody the game teaches the player, which is unambiguously in F Lydian; in fact, I doubt a more immediately recognizable example of Lydian‚Äôs major third and augmented fourth exists in anything that qualifies as popular music. (The Lost Woods theme‚Äôs official name is, shockingly, ‚ÄúLost Woods‚Äù.)
  • Mixolydian:
    • Guns N‚Äô Roses‚Äô ‚ÄúSweet Child o‚Äô Mine‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/oMfMUfgjiLg⟩ (Appetite for Destruction, 1987) is in C‚ôØ Mixolydian.
    • Nirvana‚Äôs ‚ÄúAll Apologies‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/aWmkuH1k7uA⟩ (In Utero, 1993) is also in C‚ôØ Mixolydian.
  • Aeolian: Examples of natural minor are almost as ubiquitous as examples of Ionian, but here are two songs with chords that unambiguously emphasize the Aeolian scale‚Äôs characteristics:
    • Phil Collins‚Äô ‚ÄúIn the Air Tonight‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/YkADj0TPrJA⟩ (Face Value, 1981) is in D Aeolian.
    • R.E.M.‚Äôs ‚ÄúLosing My Religion‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/xwtdhWltSIg⟩ (Out of Time, 1991) is in A Aeolian.
  • Locrian:
    • Bobby Prince‚Äôs ‚ÄúAt Doom‚Äôs Gate‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/BSsfjHCFosw⟩ (Doom, 1993) is primarily in E Locrian; it also harmonizes some of its chords over (in order) A Locrian, C‚ôØ Locrian, and B Locrian scales (though it also throws in numerous accidentals to make its riffs sound even more dissonant). Mick Gordon‚Äôs remake ⟨youtu.be/Jly9qp40rfw⟩ for Doom (2016) features a riff near the end that purely uses the D Locrian scale. (I was going to write that I couldn‚Äôt remember any well-known examples of this mode until I remembered this one.)
    • Nobuo Uematsu‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Mines of Narshe‚Äù ⟨youtu.be/LjINx71jAfs⟩ (Final Fantasy VI, 1994) opens in B Locrian, though as is common with pieces in Locrian mode, it arguably modulates away from it for part of its running time. Nonetheless, it is an unambiguous example of Locrian, given that it only uses the B half-diminished 7th chord for about twelve measures straight and provides a good example of using the mode for a mysterious, film noir-type vibe that doesn‚Äôt feel dissonant. This is probably the least famous example on this list, but I felt it to be an especially good example of Locrian‚Äôs tonality since it contains numerous uses of F‚ôÆ and C‚ôÆ, which emphasizes that the piece is, in fact, in B Locrian.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

The Modes in ‚ÄúCircle of Fifths‚Äù Order

I won‚Äôt be analyzing the modes in their traditional order, since I‚Äôm analyzing how lowering a regular pattern of notes by a half-step each enables us to walk through every mode on every key. A few notes (pun intended):

  • Most of this analysis focuses on twelve-tone equal temperament (12-TET for short), the tuning system the vast majority of Western music has used for hundreds of years. Where exceptions to what I write exist in other temperaments, I will attempt to note them, but I can‚Äôt promise to have thought of them all, especially because my understanding of other tuning systems is spotty at best.
  • For the most part, I will attempt to avoid bogging this analysis down in heavy mathematics, but I must begin this analysis by noting that in 12-TET, every note on the chromatic scale vibrates at exactly 2¹⁄₁₂ its immediate neighbor‚Äôs frequency – that is, the notes are spaced exactly evenly. This is an important precondition for the analysis I‚Äôve conducted here: much of it wouldn‚Äôt apply otherwise.
  • In 12-TET, A‚ôØ and B‚ô≠ represent the same pitch. Likewise B and C‚ô≠, C‚ôØ and D‚ô≠, and so on. However, in terms of music theory, A‚ôØ and B‚ô≠ can be semantically quite different in some contexts ‚Äì be careful.
  • Key signatures with seven sharps or seven flats exist, but I‚Äôve mostly omitted them from my analysis of Ionian‚Äôs modes. (There are even monstrosities with double-sharps [ùÑ™] and double-flats [ùÑ´] ‚Ä¶ which I mostly ignore. I can at least tolerate the double-flat symbol, but the double-sharp is a monstrosity that doesn‚Äôt resemble even slightly the thing it‚Äôs supposed to double.) I feel it was extravagant enough just to include both six-flat and six-sharp key signatures.
  • If we start from Lydian mode, lowering the correct pitches one at a time by a half-step each gives us the next mode in the cycle. I‚Äôll use C Lydian as an example to demonstrate the principle:
Modes Descending from Lydian⁽¹⁾
# Root & mode Pitch lowered 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 1
4C Lydian ‚ÄìC D E F‚ôØG A B C
1C Ionian 4C D E F G A B C
5C Mixolydian7C D E F G A B‚ô≠C
2C Dorian 3C D E‚ô≠F G A B‚ô≠C
6C Aeolian 6C D E‚ô≠F G A‚ô≠B‚ô≠C
3C Phrygian 2C D‚ô≠E‚ô≠F G A‚ô≠B‚ô≠C
7C Locrian 5C D‚ô≠E‚ô≠F G‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠C
4C‚ô≠Lydian 1C‚ô≠D‚ô≠E‚ô≠F G‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠C‚ô≠
  • In other words:
    • Lowering C Lydian‚Äôs F‚ôØ to F gives us C Ionian (i.e., C major).
    • Lowering C Ionian‚Äôs B to B‚ô≠ gives us C Mixolydian.
    • And so on, until we reach C Locrian ‚Äì whence the pattern repeats for C‚ô≠/B, the key below C on the chromatic scale.
  • Lowering Locrian‚Äôs root gives us Lydian mode in the key below it on the chromatic scale.
    • In other words, lowering C Locrian‚Äôs C to C‚ô≠/B gives us C‚ô≠/B Lydian.
  • The sequence repeats from there:
    • Lowering B Lydian‚Äôs E‚ôØ gives us B Ionian.
    • Lowering B Ionian‚Äôs A‚ôØ gives us B Mixolydian.
  • This sequence will repeat for every note on the chromatic scale: C, C‚ô≠/B, B‚ô≠/A‚ôØ, A, A‚ô≠/G‚ôØ, G, G‚ô≠/F‚ôØ, F, F‚ô≠/E, E‚ô≠/D‚ôØ, D, D‚ô≠/C‚ôØ, and back to C.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

The Principles of Inverse Operations

  • Now, note that we‚Äôve effectively been subtracting 1 from a regular pattern of values in a sequence:
    • 4, 7, 3, 6, 2, 5, 1, 4, 7, 3, 6, 2, 5, 1‚Ä¶
  • As a result, if we consult the mathematical properties of inverse operations, we can infer that converse of everything we‚Äôve just done will apply if we add 1 to the same notes in the reverse order:
    • 1, 5, 2, 6, 3, 7, 4, 1, 5, 2, 6, 3, 7, 4‚Ä¶
  • In other words:
    • Raising C‚ô≠ Lydian‚Äôs C‚ô≠ gives us C Locrian.
    • Raising C Locrian‚Äôs G‚ô≠ gives us C Phrygian.
    • Raising C Phrygian‚Äôs D‚ô≠ gives us C Aeolian.
    • And so on.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

An Audio Demonstration

  • None of this will mean much to readers in isolation, so I put together a crude demonstration of the above principle ⟨aaronfreed.github.io/c_lydian_to_b_lydian.flac⟩ in Logic Pro. For the following modes, in order:
    1. C Lydian
    2. C Ionian
    3. C Mixolydian
    4. C Dorian
    5. C Aeolian
    6. C Phrygian
    7. C Locrian
    8. C‚ô≠/B Lydian
    you‚Äôll hear the following, in order:
    1. the scale in ascending order
    2. arpeggiated and block versions of:
      1. the root (I) chord
      2. the subdominant (IV) chord
      3. the dominant (V) chord
      4. the root (I) chord
    (I could make a version going down the entire chromatic scale, but the entire thing would take thirteen and a half minutes to play through. Even I think that‚Äôs overkill, and I submit this exact page as exhibit A for what my definition of ‚Äúoverkill‚Äù must entail.)

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Further Notes

  • It might help solidify your conception of this principle to understand that while we‚Äôre lowering (or raising) a pitch on our scale, we‚Äôre also, in a sense, jumping down (or up) a fifth. F Lydian is in the same key signature as C Ionian, not F Ionian. This is why so many of these patterns mirror the circle of fifths.
  • In ‚ÄúModes Descending from Lydian‚Äù above, the mode number and the pitch we lower to get it are exact mirrors of each other. This is not coincidental ‚Äì it‚Äôs the direct result of a mathematical pattern.
  • The modes are also always either three steps on the scale below their predecessors (usually, but not always, a perfect fourth), or four steps above (usually, but not always, a perfect fifth). In this context, they‚Äôre equivalent, since the scale repeats every octave.
    • Although this is only somewhat relevant here, one pair of intervals always constitutes an exception to the ‚Äúperfect fourths‚Äù and ‚Äúperfect fifths‚Äù rules: one fourth is always augmented, and one fifth is always diminished. These are actually the same interval, a tritone. The following steps on each scale are tritones in either direction:
      Diabolus in mūsicā
      #Mode Tritone
      4Lydian 41
      1Ionian 74
      5Mixolydian37
      2Dorian 63
      6Aeolian 26
      3Phrygian 52
      7Locrian 15
      Note that the third columns of ‚ÄúDiabolus in mūsicā‚Äù and of ‚ÄúModes Descending from Lydian‚Äù are identical. This is also not coincidental.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

The Major Scale‚Äôs Modes & the Circle of Fifths

12 Major Scales × 7 Modes = 84 Combinations

  • I‚Äôve printed the C major scale‚Äôs modes in bold, blue type to make them stand out. These are the only scales played using only the white keys of the piano (this is also why music notation can express these specific keys without accidentals, either in the key signature or after it). The differences between their numbers are always multiples of twelve; this is also not a coincidence.
  • Halfway between C major‚Äôs modes, I always print a mode twice, in orange, with its key signature first using six flats (G‚ô≠ major), then six sharps (F‚ôØ major). I don‚Äôt really like either option (E‚ôØ is F‚ôÆ! C‚ô≠ is B‚ôÆ!), but both avoid a repeated letter in a scale, and thus a rash of accidentals in the notation of any piece that uses them. G‚ô≠/F‚ôØ major‚Äôs modes are also always separated by multiples of twelve, for the same reason: this progression separates all seven modes of each scale from each other by multiples of twelve.
  • I‚Äôve listed these descending by pitch so higher pitches will be, well, higher, which may confuse some people since we read from top to bottom and are used to thinking of harmony in ascending order. Someday, I plan to write a JavaScript add-on to give readers an option to reverse the order ‚Äì and eventually, to give them then option to create similar tables for different scales (at the bare minimum, melodic minor, harmonic minor, and chromatic Hypolydian; possibly others as well).
  • ‚ÄúRM‚Äù is an initialism for ‚ÄúRelative Major‚Äù, and ‚ÄúKS‚Äù is for ‚ÄúKey Signature‚Äù. A cheat sheet for what modes use what key signatures can be found in the section immediately following this one.
  • I‚Äôve used zero-based indexing for these tables, so they‚Äôre indexed from zero to eighty-three. This is partly because I prefer zero-based indexing, but to be honest, it was mostly to give C Ionian an index of one.
C   (B‚ôØ)
# Root Mode RMKS1 2 3 4 5 6 7 1
 0C‚ôÆ4 ‚Äì Lydian G 1‚ôØ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
 1C‚ôÆ1 ‚Äì Ionian C ‚ôÆ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
 2C‚ôÆ5 ‚Äì MixolydianF 1‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ
 3C‚ôÆ2 ‚Äì Dorian B‚ô≠ 2‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ
 4C‚ôÆ6 ‚Äì Aeolian E‚ô≠ 3‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ
 5C‚ôÆ3 ‚Äì Phrygian A‚ô≠ 4‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ
 6C‚ôÆ7 ‚Äì Locrian D‚ô≠ 5‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ

Key Signature Cheat Sheet

  • Twelve-tone equal temperament has fifteen key signatures, ùÑ™/ùÑ´ atrocities notwithstanding:
Key Signatures of the Seven Modes for the Twelve-Note Chromatic Scale
LydMajMixDorMin PhrLoc KS A B C D E F G
F‚ôØC‚ôØG‚ôØD‚ôØA‚ôØE‚ôØB‚ôØ7‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ
B F‚ôØC‚ôØG‚ôØD‚ôØA‚ôØE‚ôØ6‚ôØ‚ôØ ‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ‚ôØ
E B F‚ôØC‚ôØG‚ôØD‚ôØA‚ôØ5‚ôØ‚ôØ ‚ôØ‚ôØ ‚ôØ‚ôØ
A E B F‚ôØC‚ôØG‚ôØD‚ôØ4‚ôØ ‚ôØ‚ôØ ‚ôØ‚ôØ
D A E B F‚ôØC‚ôØG‚ôØ3‚ôØ ‚ôØ ‚ôØ‚ôØ
G D A E B F‚ôØC‚ôØ2‚ôØ ‚ôØ ‚ôØ
C G D A E B F‚ôØ1‚ôØ ‚ôØ
F C G D A E B ‚ôÆ
B‚ô≠F C G D A E 1‚ô≠ ‚ô≠
E‚ô≠B‚ô≠F C G D A 2‚ô≠ ‚ô≠ ‚ô≠
A‚ô≠E‚ô≠B‚ô≠F C G D 3‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠ ‚ô≠
D‚ô≠A‚ô≠E‚ô≠B‚ô≠F C G 4‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠ ‚ô≠‚ô≠
G‚ô≠D‚ô≠A‚ô≠E‚ô≠B‚ô≠F C 5‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠ ‚ô≠‚ô≠ ‚ô≠
C‚ô≠G‚ô≠D‚ô≠A‚ô≠E‚ô≠B‚ô≠F 6‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠ ‚ô≠
F‚ô≠C‚ô≠G‚ô≠D‚ô≠A‚ô≠E‚ô≠B‚ô≠7‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠‚ô≠
  • Legend for the above:
    • Lyd = Lydian
    • Maj = major (Ionian)
    • Mix = Mixolydian
    • Dor = Dorian (if you‚Äôre not sure why it‚Äôs grey, ask your English teacher about the picture)
    • Min = natural minor (Aeolian)
    • Phr = Phrygian
    • Loc = Locrian
    • KS = key signature (highlighted because it‚Äôs the key to the table ‚Äì pun coincidental, though I definitely didn‚Äôt even try to avoid it)
  • Additional notes:
    • 5‚ôØ and 7‚ô≠ express the same pitches.
    • 6‚ôØ and 6‚ô≠ express the same pitches.
    • 7‚ôØ and 5‚ô≠ express the same pitches.
    • I‚Äôve again printed C major‚Äôs modes in blue and F‚ôØ/G‚ô≠ major‚Äôs modes in orange.
  • Accidentals also fall onto the circle of fifths (e.g., B‚ô≠ to E‚ô≠ and E‚ô≠ to A‚ô≠ are both perfect fifths).

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Why is this happening?

The simple answer: whether we realized it or not, we‚Äôve been traversing the circle of fifths this entire time. My introduction notes that traveling from C Lydian to C Ionian is, in a sense, traveling from G major to C major. Here‚Äôs the C table again. Note Relative Major‚Äôs traversal down the circle of fifths:

C++
# Root Mode RMKS1 2 3 4 5 6 7 1
 0C‚ôÆ4 ‚Äì Lydian G 1‚ôØ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
 1C‚ôÆ1 ‚Äì Ionian C ‚ôÆ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
 2C‚ôÆ5 ‚Äì MixolydianF 1‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ
 3C‚ôÆ2 ‚Äì Dorian B‚ô≠ 2‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ
 4C‚ôÆ6 ‚Äì Aeolian E‚ô≠ 3‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ
 5C‚ôÆ3 ‚Äì Phrygian A‚ô≠ 4‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ
 6C‚ôÆ7 ‚Äì Locrian D‚ô≠ 5‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆ

The explanation is that each of these modes, apart from C Ionian, has been rearranging a different major scale. Reshuffling each mode back into its Ionian form may explain the cause:

You were expecting modes, but it was me, Dio the circle of fifths!
# Original Mode Root KS1 2 3 4 5 6 7 1
 04 ‚Äì Lydian G 1‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆ
 11 ‚Äì Ionian C ‚ôÆ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
 25 ‚Äì MixolydianF 1‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ
 32 ‚Äì Dorian B‚ô≠2‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠
 46 ‚Äì Aeolian E‚ô≠3‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠
 53 ‚Äì Phrygian A‚ô≠4‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠
 67 ‚Äì Locrian D‚ô≠5‚ô≠ D‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ C‚ôÆD‚ô≠

Every note of every scale in this table is, in fact, a perfect fifth below its counterpart in its predecessor. Almost every other pattern we‚Äôve observed that follows the circle of fifths in some way is a direct consequence of this.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Chord Analysis by Mode

Chord Tonalities by Scale Position & Mode
ModeIIIIIIIVVVIVII
1Ionian Majminmin Maj Majmindim
2Dorian minmin Maj Majmindim Maj
3Phrygian min Maj Majmindim Majmin
4Lydian Maj Majmindim Majminmin
5Mixolydian Majmindim Majminmin Maj
6Aeolian mindim Majminmin Maj Maj
7Locrian dim Majminmin Maj Majmin
  • I‚Äôve printed each mode‚Äôs root (I) subdominant (IV), and dominant (V) chords in bold ‚Äì they‚Äôre especially important to establishing its tonality.
  • I‚Äôve printed the seventh chord in fainter text because it‚Äôs diminished in the major scale.
  • Minor chords are blue; diminished chords are orange.
  • This analysis clarifies why Ionian became the standard major scale and Aeolian became the natural minor scale: Ionian‚Äôs root, subdominant, and dominant are all major; Aeolian‚Äôs are all minor. This makes them feel, respectively, especially major and especially minor.
  • Since their root chords are major, Lydian and Mixolydian still sound more ‚Äúmajor‚Äù than the other modes (except Ionian), and Dorian and Phrygian still sound more ‚Äúminor‚Äù than the others (except Aeolian). Locrian, as mentioned, is the oddball because it‚Äôs the only mode of the scale whose root chord is diminished.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Beyond the Major Scale

Other Scales & Tonalities

While the above analysis focuses exclusively on the Ionian scale‚Äôs modes, numerous possible scales (and modes thereof) don‚Äôt fit its pattern, many of which I‚Äôll now analyze. Some examples:

  • The twelve-note chromatic scale (though works that use the entire twelve-note scale for non-colorative purposes are quite rare and are mostly considered avant-garde).
  • Numerous heptatonic (seven-note) scales that aren‚Äôt modes of the major scale. I‚Äôve rooted the following examples (many of which are common in jazz) in C to make it clear how they change the Ionian scale:
    Other Heptatonic Scales
    Scale 1 234567Intervals
    Chromatic DorianKanakƒÅngiC‚ôÆD‚ô≠EùÑ´F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠BùÑ´¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
    Mixolydian ‚ôØ1Super-Locrian ‚ô≠7C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ô≠A‚ô≠BùÑ´¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω
    Locrian ‚ô≠4Super-LocrianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω1111
    Locrian ‚ôØ6Maqam TarznauynC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1
    Dorian ‚ô≠2Jazz minor inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω1111¬Ω1
    Phrygian ‚ôØ3Phrygian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11
    Major PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
    Aeolian ‚ô≠5Half-diminishedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω111
    Harmonic minor ‚ô≠5C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω
    Aeolian ‚ôØ7Harmonic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
    Ionian ‚ô≠3Melodic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω1111¬Ω
    Double harmonic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
    Dorian ‚ôØ4Lydian diminishedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1
    Mixolydian ‚ô≠6Aeolian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠11¬Ω1¬Ω11
    Ionian ‚ôØ5Ionian augmentedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
    Lydian ‚ô≠7Lydian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠111¬Ω1¬Ω1
    Phrygian ‚ô≠1Lydian augmentedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1111¬Ω1¬Ω
    Chromatic Dorian inverseC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
    Lydian ‚ôØ2Aeolian harmonicC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω
    Chromatic HypophrygianC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôØF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
    Superlydian augmentedC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôØF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôØB‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω

    Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

    Since many scales have up to dozens of names (if you‚Äôre on a computer, hover over dotted scale names for more information), I‚Äôve instead used the sorting methods of Southern India‚Äôs Carnatic Numbered Mƒì·∏∑akartƒÅ, which effectively alphabetize the scales themselves: sort intervals in ascending order, with the lowest intervals counting as most significant. (¬ß9 lists the mƒì·∏∑akartƒÅ in full; note that they categorically exclude scales with flat fourths, flat fifths, or sharp fifths.) Bold, orange text denotes raised notes and minor thirds; thin, blue text denotes lowered notes and minor seconds (doubly lowered notes are also fainter).

    This list is far from exhaustive. Note that none of these scales use B‚ôØ because, while it‚Äôs semantically different from C, the two notes represent the same pitch in twelve-tone equal temperament. Likewise, none of these scales use DùÑ´ because it‚Äôs the same pitch as C.

    In any case, one thing distinguishes these scales from the Ionian scale‚Äôs modes: we can print the latter with no accidentals outside the key signature, but every single scale in the above table requires accidentals for at least some notes. Key signatures are strictly based on the Ionian scale and the circle of fifths; using three flats that weren‚Äôt B‚ô≠, E‚ô≠, and A‚ô≠ in a key signature would just confuse readers.

    The names ‚ÄúChromatic Dorian‚Äù and ‚ÄúChromatic Hypophrygian‚Äù will reappear below in the section on ancient Greek harmony below. (Don‚Äôt waste time trying to discern their connections to the similarly named diatonic modes: Chromatic Dorian actually relates to Phrygian, and Chromatic Hypophrygian to Mixolydian. The section on Greek harmony explains the relationships, and why they aren‚Äôt the ones their names suggest.)

  • Note that several sets of the above scales are modes of each other. In particular:

    Harmonic Minor & Melodic Minor‚Äôs Modes at a Glance
    Scale 1 234567Intervals
    Aeolian ‚ôØ7 Harmonic minor C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ 1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
    Locrian ‚ôØ6 Maqam Tarznauyn C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ô≠ ¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1
    Ionian ‚ôØ5 Ionian augmented C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
    Dorian ‚ôØ4 Lydian diminished C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1
    Phrygian ‚ôØ3 Phrygian dominant C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11
    Lydian ‚ôØ2 Aeolian harmonic C‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω
    Mixolydian ‚ôØ1 Super-Locrian ‚ô≠7 C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ô≠A‚ô≠BùÑ´ ¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω
    Ionian ‚ô≠3 Melodic minor C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1111¬Ω
    Dorian ‚ô≠2 Jazz minor inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ ¬Ω1111¬Ω1
    Phrygian ‚ô≠1 Lydian augmented C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1111¬Ω1¬Ω
    Lydian ‚ô≠7 Lydian dominant C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 111¬Ω1¬Ω1
    Mixolydian ‚ô≠6 Aeolian dominant C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠ 11¬Ω1¬Ω11
    Aeolian ‚ô≠5Half-diminished C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠ 1¬Ω1¬Ω111
    Locrian ‚ô≠4Super-Locrian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠ ¬Ω1¬Ω1111

    Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

    We can apply similar principles to them as we applied to the Ionian scale‚Äôs modes, though certain things may not line up as neatly with some of the scales. I leave ascertaining which other sets of scales are modes of each other as an exercise for the reader. (I didn‚Äôt list every mode of most other sets of scales.) The next two sections analyze these modes in much greater depth.

    Note that two competing shorthands exist for transformations like ‚ÄúAeolian ‚ôØ7‚Äù, relative to either:

    1. The current note: ‚Äú‚ôØ7‚Äù always means ‚Äúraise the base scale‚Äôs seventh note half a step‚Äù. If it‚Äôs currently A‚ô≠, make it A‚ôÆ. If it‚Äôs currently A, make it A‚ôØ. If it‚Äôs currently C‚ôØ, make it (ugh) CùÑ™ (and Jesus wept, for there were no more worlds to conquer‚Ä¶ wait, that‚Äôs not how it goes).
    2. The C scale‚Äôs accidental: C Aeolian 7 is B‚ô≠, so ‚ÄòAeolian ‚ôÆ7‚Äô = ‚Äòraise Aeolian‚Äôs seventh note half a step‚Äô.

    Not gonna front: I despise the latter with the burning passion of a thousand suns. ‚Äú‚ôØ7‚Äù applies independently of the root, while in any key except C, ‚Äú‚ôÆ7‚Äù requires asking ‚Äúwait, what accidental is on C Aeolian 7?‚Äù C‚ôØ Aeolian 7 is already B‚ôÆ, so what does ‚ÄúC‚ôØ Aeolian ‚ôÆ7‚Äù even tell us? F‚ôØ Aeolian 7 is C‚ôØ, so if we read ‚ÄúF‚ôØ Aeolian ‚ôÆ7‚Äù literally, we‚Äôd lower the seventh note by a half-step ‚Äì exactly the opposite of what it intends!

    Then again, ‚ÄúLydian ‚ôÆ4‚Äù (‚Äúlower Lydian‚Äôs fourth note a half-step‚Äù) and ‚ÄúMixolydian ‚ôÆ7‚Äù (‚Äúraise Mixolydian‚Äôs seventh note a half-step‚Äù) make for the most pretentious possible ways to say ‚Äúmajor‚Äù this side of ¬´Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÑŒøŒΩŒπŒ∫œåœÇ Œõ·ø°ÃÅŒ¥·øêŒøœÇ œÑœåŒΩŒøœÇ¬ª (‚Äúdiatonic Lydian tonos‚Äù; see the section on Ancient Greek harmony below), so I guess there is one actual upside to the C-based convention.

Beyond Pentatonic and Heptatonic Scales

Of course, there‚Äôs nothing saying scales have to contain only seven notes. I‚Äôm going to leave off analysis of pentatonic (five-note) scales for a moment, because it turns out there‚Äôs a lot to unpack with them. Let‚Äôs start with a brief overview of everything else.

  • Hexatonic (six-note) scales are also fairly common (including whole-tone scales).
  • Scales are also not limited to seven notes; blues and jazz often use octatonic (eight-note) and enneatonic (nine-note) scales. Decatonic (ten-note) scales are slightly less common, but still occur.
  • Twelve-tone equal temperament only allows for one possible hendecatonic (eleven-note) scale, though it does have eleven separate modes. Do you understand why? (Hint: There‚Äôs only a single dodecatonic scale in our tuning system for exactly the same reason.)
  • The above, of course, has all been based on the twelve-tone equal temperament (12-TET) ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/12_equal_temperament⟩ used in the vast majority of Western music from the last five centuries. Plenty of other tunings have been and still are used, though; there‚Äôs nothing even restricting the number of notes per octave to twelve. For instance:
    • A twenty-four-note scale ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarter_tone⟩ is common in Arabic and Turkic music.
    • Indian rāgas ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raga⟩⁽²⁾ (similar to scales) typically use four to seven svaras⁽³⁾ (similar to scale tones) of the twenty-two śrútis ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shruti_(music)⟩⁽⁴⁾ (which collectively aren‚Äôt exactly 22-TET, but not entirely unlike it).
    • Experimental Western musicians also occasionally use alternate temperaments. Here are a few recent rock and metal examples, in increasing order of heaviness:
      • Flying Microtonal Banana ⟨kinggizzard.bandcamp.com/album/flying-microtonal-banana⟩ by King Giz­zard & the Lizard Wizard (24-TET)
      • Nowherer ⟨votsband.bandcamp.com/album/nowherer⟩ by Victory over the Sun (17-TET)
      • any metal album by Jute Gyte ⟨jutegyte.bandcamp.com/music⟩ since Discontinuities (24-TET)
    • As we‚Äôll see when we discuss Ancient Greece, their enharmonic genus also used microtonality. (Note: enharmonic varies wildly in meaning based on context. In 12-TET, two enharmonic notes have the same pitch. In microtonal tunings, they‚Äôre about as dissonant as you can get.)

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

The Pentatonic Scale

As complement of Ionian

Pentatonic (five-note, ‚Äú5t‚Äù for short) scales are ubiquitous in rock, blues, and jazz, though they‚Äôre much older than that and exist in many cultures. The most common pentatonic scale is literally Ionian‚Äôs scale complement.

What exactly is a scale complement? It‚Äôs the equivalent of a binary XOR. Say we represent a scale as a set of twelve 1s (‚Äúthis tone is part of the scale‚Äù) or 0s (‚Äúthis tone is not part of the scale‚Äù). Now, flip all the bits. Tones that had notes are no longer part of the scale; tones that didn‚Äôt now are. That‚Äôs the complement.

This means we can play the pentatonic scale using all the piano keys we didn‚Äôt use to play Ionian. Whenever I write ‚Äúthe pentatonic scale‚Äù, preceded by the definite article, I mean this pentatonic scale. To wit:

  • C Ionian only uses the white keys on the piano: C, D, E, F, G, A, B, C.
  • F‚ôØ pentatonic major only uses the black keys: F‚ôØ, G‚ôØ, A‚ôØ, C‚ôØ, D‚ôØ (or G‚ô≠, A‚ô≠, B‚ô≠, D‚ô≠, E‚ô≠, if you‚Äôre nasty prefer flats).

To a huge extent, the pentatonic and Ionian scales‚Äô relationship even extends to their modes. For instance:

  • Starting C Ionian three semitones early creates its relative minor, A Aeolian.
  • Starting F‚ôØ pentatonic major three semitones early creates its relative minor, D‚ôØ/E‚ô≠ pentatonic minor.

As truncation of Ionian

Conveniently, though, it‚Äôs not just a complement, though: it‚Äôs also a truncation. We can get the pentatonic scale simply by deleting two notes of Ionian. As a result, the two scales‚Äô modes correspond in countless ways.

Since the pentatonic scale has two fewer notes than Ionian, our analysis must delete two modes. But which two? We can derive the pentatonic scale from Ionian using at least three different methods.

A quick warning before we proceed further: we‚Äôre about to take a quick detour into ‚Äúright for the wrong reasons‚Äù land. After the third table, I‚Äôll explain how, why, and where the first two tables go wrong.

Let‚Äôs try disregarding Phrygian and Locrian, the lowest modes in the circle of fifths progression. In this analysis:

  • Major pentatonic deletes Lydian‚Äôs fourth and seventh notes: F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ (1, 1, 1¬Ω, 1, 1¬Ω).
  • Scottish pentatonic deletes Ionian‚Äôs third and seventh notes: C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ (1, 1¬Ω, 1, 1, 1¬Ω).
  • Neutral pentatonic deletes Mixolydian‚Äôs third and sixth notes: G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôØ (1, 1¬Ω, 1, 1¬Ω, 1). Neutral pentatonic is comparable to Dorian mode in two ways: it is a symmetrical scale, and it‚Äôs the midpoint of the pentatonic circle of fifths order (which is complex enough to merit its own section below).
  • Minor pentatonic deletes Dorian‚Äôs second and sixth notes: D‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôØ (1¬Ω, 1, 1, 1¬Ω, 1).
  • Blues minor deletes Aeolian‚Äôs second and fifth notes: A‚ôØ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ (1¬Ω, 1, 1¬Ω, 1, 1).

Got all that? Let‚Äôs recap. (Note: ‚ÄúH‚Äù = half-tone, ‚ÄùW‚Äù = whole tone, ‚ÄúM‚Äù = minor third)

The incorrect ‚Äúupshift‚Äù hypothesis
[7t]   Mode   [5t][7t]   Piano keys   [5t][7t]   Intervals   [5t]Del
Lydian Major 5t. F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ W W W H W W H W W M W M 4 7
Ionian Scottish 5t. C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ W W H W W W H W M W W M 3 7
Mixolydian Neutral 5t. G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôØ W W H W W H W W M W M W 3 6
Dorian Minor 5t. D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC D‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôØ W H W W W H W M W W M W 2 6
Aeolian Blues Minor A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG A‚ôØ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ W H W W H W W M W M W W 2 5

I probably don‚Äôt even need to point out how many patterns recur in both scales.

We just analyzed the pentatonic modes based on notes a half-step above them, but we could just as easily have used the notes a half-step above. This means instead disregarding Lydian and Ionian. Oddly enough, we delete the same scale degrees either way:

The incorrect ‚Äúdownshift‚Äù hypothesis
[7t]   Mode   [5t][7t]   Piano keys   [5t][7t]   Intervals   [5t]Del
Mixolydian Major 5t. G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF G‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ D‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ W W H W W H W W W M W M 4 7
Dorian Scottish 5t. D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC D‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ G‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ W H W W W H W W M W W M 3 7
Aeolian Neutral 5t. A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ D‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ G‚ô≠ W H W W H W W W M W M W 3 6
Phrygian Minor 5t. E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD E‚ô≠ G‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ D‚ô≠ H W W W H W W M W W M W 2 6
Locrian Blues Minor B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA B‚ô≠ D‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ G‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ H W W H W W W M W M W W 2 5

(End warning.)

We have to go deeper (Scaleception)

But wait, there‚Äôs more! Consulting the heptatonic circle of fifths progression enables us to ‚Äúaverage‚Äù the above two tables. Eerily, averaging them doesn‚Äôt invalidate their results in any way except a trivial one: this is the first analysis that‚Äôs actually correct. But, as the famed philosopher Nigel Tufnel put it, that‚Äôs nitpicking, innit?

How pentatonic transforms Ionian: The correct ‚Äútritone deletion‚Äù explanation
[7t]   Mode   [5t][7t]   Piano keys   [5t][7t]   Intervals   [5t]Del
Ionian Major 5t. C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA W W H W W W H W W M W M 4 7
Mixolydian Scottish 5t. G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF G‚ôÆA‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE W W H W W H W W M W W M 3 7
Dorian Neutral 5t. D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC D‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆC W H W W W H W W M W M W 3 6
Aeolian Minor 5t. A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG A‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG W H W W H W W M W W M W 2 6
Phrygian Blues Minor E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD E‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆC‚ôÆD H W W W H W W M W M W W 2 5

So, to reiterate: The first two tables I presented are filthy half-truths: their explanations only fit due to mathematical patterns they don‚Äôt account for. Only the third is fully correct. Can you figure out why?

  1. If both scales have symmetrical modes (Dorian and neutral pentatonic), then:
    1. We should compare the symmetrical modes to each other.
    2. Symmetrical modes should be their circle-of-fifths-order comparisons‚Äô center data rows.
    3. Rows whose intervals are mirrors in the base should remain mirrors in the transformation.
    4. Both circle-of-fifths-order interval comparisons should possess 180¬∞ rotational symmetry.
    All of these are false in the first two tables and true in the third.
  2. Since we didn‚Äôt delete the root, our analysis must compare the base scales. Only table three does so. Not comparing the base scales is a surefire recipe for confusion.
  3. Deleting the base scale‚Äôs fourth and seventh notes also deletes its fourth and seventh modes. The first table keeps Lydian. The second keeps Locrian. The third deletes both.
  4. Our analysis must compare the same notes within each scale. We didn‚Äôt move notes, only remove them, so our analysis can‚Äôt either. A closer look at the ‚Äúdownshift‚Äù table reveals the problem here: Mixolydian‚Äôs fourth degree, Dorian‚Äôs seventh, Aeolian‚Äôs third, Phrygian‚Äôs sixth, and Locrian‚Äôs second are Ionian‚Äôs root!

    The problem isn‚Äôt as obvious in the ‚Äúupshift‚Äù table, but it tells us to remove Ionian‚Äôs third degree. Major pentatonic still opens with two whole steps, just like Ionian, so we haven‚Äôt removed Ionian‚Äôs third degree! This is why our analysis should only shift notes if we delete the root. (And if you do, good luck ‚Äì¬†you‚Äôll need it.)

I struggled with whether to call the last table ‚ÄúTritone Deletion‚Äù, ‚ÄúTritone Substitution‚Äù, or ‚ÄúTritone Shift‚Äù; all three are correct. The notes the last table removes correspond exactly to the Ionian scale‚Äôs sole tritone; the pentatonic scales are also exactly a tritone from where its two predecessors listed them. I ultimately went with ‚ÄúTritone Deletion‚Äù, though, because all the properties above are direct consequences of removing the tritone.

Things like this are one reason I self-identify as agnostic rather than atheist: part of my brain refuses to accept that these could be coincidences. (The other part of my brain replies that this is all mathematically inevitable, and I simply haven‚Äôt yet grokked all the implications of deleting Ionian‚Äôs fourth and seventh notes.)

Since pentatonic‚Äôs mode nomenclature isn‚Äôt as well established as Ionian‚Äôs, my brain‚Äôs cutesy part wants to rename them Nianoi, Niadyloxim, Niarod, Nialoea, and Niagyrhp. I‚Äôm afraid that even after the above explanation, that might confuse people, but that won‚Äôt stop me from using them as alternate names.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Analysis of modes in scale order

The modes‚Äô scale ordering may help further clarify why the upshift and downshift tables are wrong:

How pentatonic transforms Ionian: The correct ‚Äúroot note‚Äù explanation
[7t]   Mode   [5t][7t]   Piano keys   [5t][7t]   Intervals   [5t]Del
Ionian Major 5t. C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA W W H W W W H W W M W M 4 7
Dorian Neutral 5t. D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC D‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆC W H W W W H W W M W M W 3 6
Phrygian Blues Minor E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD E‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆC‚ôÆD H W W W H W W M W M W W 2 5
Mixolydian Scottish 5t. G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF G‚ôÆA‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE W W H W W H W W M W W M 3 7
Aeolian Minor 5t. A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG A‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG W H W W H W W M W W M W 2 6

Modes are inextricably linked to their roots. We must compare the same notes in each scale:

  1. We didn‚Äôt delete this note, so its mode, Ionian, becomes major pentatonic.
  2. We didn‚Äôt delete this note, so its mode, Dorian, becomes neutral pentatonic.
  3. We didn‚Äôt delete this note, so its mode, Phrygian, becomes blues minor.
  4. Deleting this note deletes its mode. Lydian has no pentatonic equivalent.
  5. We didn‚Äôt delete this note, so its mode, Mixolydian, becomes Scottish pentatonic.
  6. We didn‚Äôt delete this note, so its mode, Aeolian, becomes minor pentatonic.
  7. Deleting this note deletes its mode. Locrian has no pentatonic equivalent.

Put another way, recall how Ionian‚Äôs modes got their numbering:

  1. Ionian starts on its first note.
  2. Dorian starts on its second note.
  3. Phrygian starts on its third note.
  4. Lydian starts on its fourth note.
  5. Mixolydian starts on its fifth note.
  6. Aeolian starts on its sixth note.
  7. Locrian starts on its seventh note.

So, applying the same principle to the pentatonic scale:

  1. Major pentatonic starts on its first note.
  2. Neutral pentatonic starts on its second note.
  3. Blues minor starts on its third note.
  4. Scottish pentatonic starts on its fourth note.
  5. Minor pentatonic starts on its fifth note.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Comparison of interval spacing

Why pentatonic and Ionian‚Äôs intervals are out of sync may not be obvious. Let‚Äôs revisit the above table, this time with deleted tones in red and combined intervals in purple:

How pentatonic transforms Ionian: Interval analysis (circle order)
[7t]   Mode   [5t][7t]   Piano keys   [5t][7t]   Intervals   [5t]Del
Ionian Major 5t. C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA W W H W W W H W W M W M 4 7
Mixolydian Scottish 5t. G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF G‚ôÆA‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE W W H W W H W W M W W M 3 7
Dorian Neutral 5t. D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC D‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆC W H W W W H W W M W M W 3 6
Aeolian Minor 5t. A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG A‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG W H W W H W W M W W M W 2 6
Phrygian Blues Minor E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD E‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆC‚ôÆD H W W W H W W M W M W W 2 5

It may help to emphasize that we aren‚Äôt deleting intervals; we‚Äôre deleting notes and combining intervals. For instance, deleting a scale‚Äôs second note combines its first two intervals. Also, bear in mind that:

  1. Ionian has only semitones and whole tones
  2. We only delete notes that:
    1. follow semitones and precede whole tones
    2. follow whole tones and precede semitones

Thus, the two intervals around every deleted note turn become a single minor third aligning exactly to the pattern of deletions. Since this pattern is out of phase with the original one, it changes, but if the deleted notes were surrounded by different intervals, the new interval pattern wouldn‚Äôt map so precisely to the deletions.

Interestingly, that relationship is vastly less obvious in scale order, even with the above highlighting:

How pentatonic transforms Ionian: Interval analysis (scale order)
[7t]   Mode   [5t][7t]   Piano keys   [5t][7t]   Intervals   [5t]Del
Ionian Major 5t. C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA W W H W W W H W W M W M 4 7
Dorian Neutral 5t. D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC D‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆC W H W W W H W W M W M W 3 6
Phrygian Blues Minor E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD E‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆC‚ôÆD H W W W H W W M W M W W 2 5
Mixolydian Scottish 5t. G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF G‚ôÆA‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE W W H W W H W W M W W M 3 7
Aeolian Minor 5t. A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG A‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG W H W W H W W M W W M W 2 6

So, let‚Äôs correct our original analysis, shall we?

  • Major pentatonic deletes Ionian‚Äôs fourth and seventh notes: C D E G A (1, 1, 1¬Ω, 1, 1¬Ω). It is the root form of the scale, and it is the lowest mode on the pentatonic circle of fourths.
  • Scottish pentatonic deletes Mixolydian‚Äôs third and seventh notes: G A C D E (1, 1¬Ω, 1, 1, 1¬Ω). It is the second-lowest mode on the pentatonic circle of fourths.
  • Neutral pentatonic deletes Dorian‚Äôs third and sixth notes: D E G A C (1, 1¬Ω, 1, 1¬Ω, 1). Neutral pentatonic is comparable to Dorian mode in two additional ways: it is a symmetrical scale, and it‚Äôs the midpoint of the pentatonic circle of fourths order.
  • Minor pentatonic deletes Aeolian‚Äôs second and sixth notes: A C D E G (1¬Ω, 1, 1, 1¬Ω, 1). It is the second-highest mode on the pentatonic circle of fourths.
  • Blues minor deletes Phrygian‚Äôs second and fifth notes: E G A C D (1¬Ω, 1, 1¬Ω, 1, 1). It is the highest mode on the pentatonic circle of fourths.

Oh, right. Time to explain ‚Äúcircle of fourths‚Äù. Though I should probably explain scale rotation even before that.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

A Brief Explanation of Scale Rotation

Scale rotation is the practice of forming a different mode by moving some of a scale‚Äôs intervals either from its start to its end or from its end to its start. When I refer to moving a scale‚Äôs intervals ‚Äúleft‚Äù, I‚Äôm referring both to the piano keyboard and to the scale interval tables I keep using. Rotating a scale left means moving most of its intervals to a lower point in the scale. Since a scale repeats every octave, the rest move to the top.

‚ÄúIt might not always be ‚Äòmost‚Äô,‚Äù I hear you object. Well, true, you could rotate a seven-note scale six degrees to the right, but why would you, when that‚Äôs the same as rotating it one degree to the left?

‚Ä¶Oh, right. I need to explain rotation by degrees, too. No, we‚Äôre not talking angles here. Rotating a scale by a specific number of degrees moves that many intervals from the start of the scale to the end (or vice versa). Rotating Ionian one degree left gives you Dorian. Rotating Ionian three degrees left gives you Lydian. And so on.

I‚Äôll also sometimes refer to rotation by semitones. If I rotate a scale by five semitones, that means the intervals moved from the start to the end (or from the end to the start) sum up to five semitones. Thus, rotating Ionian five semitones to the left also takes you to Lydian.

The size of a scale rotation, either in interval size or in degrees, has nothing to do with how far the notes within the scale move. Lydian may be a five-semitone leftward rotation from Ionian, but it only moves one note (the fourth degree of the scale), and that note only moves by a semitone (F to F‚ôØ).

I may also refer to scale rotations by the number of notes they move. A single-note rotation only changes the position of one note. This does not signify anything about the number of intervals moved to the front or the end of the scale, the size of those intervals, or even about the interval by which the note is moved.

So, to summarize: Ionian to Lydian is a single-note rotation; it moves the note by one semitone, but it rotates the scale by five semitones (and three degrees).

I‚Äôll try to keep this terminology from being ambiguous, but words are an imperfect medium for discussing music at the best of times, and when we throw mathematics, geometry, and set theory into the mix, forget it. If anything feels confusingly worded, please let me know, and I‚Äôll try to clarify it.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

The Pentatonic Circle of Fourths, or, Contrary Motion Explained

The pentatonic and Ionian circle of fifths orders move their parent scales in exact opposite directions. In fact, to emphasize this, I‚Äôm not even gonna call it the pentatonic circle of fifths anymore. I‚Äôma call it monkeydude Josh the pentatonic circle of fourths. I find this fitting for at least two reasons:

  1. Scale analysis disregards octaves in such a way that moving up a perfect fifth equates to moving down a perfect fourth. The different nomenclature helps call attention to their contrary directions.
  2. Since the perfect fifth (seven semitones) has been the focus of my analysis of seven-note scales, the perfect fourth (five semitones) feels like the perfect focus for analysis of five-note scales.

But why do they move in opposite directions? It‚Äôs probably easiest to analyze in terms of interval spacing.

Pentatonic changes two of Ionian‚Äôs interval pairs from ‚Äútone, semitone‚Äù to ‚Äúminor third‚Äù. It so happens that one of Ionian‚Äôs two semitones closes out the scale. Thus, compare what happens when we shift pentatonic major‚Äôs intervals to the left to what happens when we shift Ionian‚Äôs.

Pentatonic interval spacing (root order)
#Mode1 2345Intervals
1Nainoi Major 5t C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ111¬Ω11¬Ω
2Nairod Neutral 5t C‚ôÆD‚ôÆF‚ôÆ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ11¬Ω11¬Ω 1
3Naigyrhp Blues Minor C‚ôÆD‚ôØ F‚ôÆ G‚ôØA‚ôØ 1¬Ω11¬Ω 11
4NaidyloximScottish 5tC‚ôÆD‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ11¬Ω111¬Ω
5Nailoea Minor 5t C‚ôÆD‚ôØF‚ôÆ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ 1¬Ω111¬Ω 1
Ionian interval spacing (root order)
#Mode1 234567Intervals
1Ionian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω
2Dorian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω 1
3Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω 1 1
4Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1 1 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω
5MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1
6Aeolian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1
7Locrian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 11

There‚Äôs a lot to unpack there. Some analysis:

Both scales contain a repeated interval set (called a tetrachord in Ionian and a trichord in pentatonic) and a spare whole step, or synaphe. I‚Äôve marked one possible reading within the interval list. (Two such readings exist of pentatonic, and three of Ionian; in this example, I avoided splitting tetrachords or trichords in the base scale.)

Synaphe comes from the Attic Greek œÉ·ø†ŒΩ·æ∞œÜŒÆ (s≈≠nƒÉphḗ, literally connection, union, junction; point or line of junction; conjunction of two tetrachords). Its Attic pronunciation is roughly suh-nuh-FAY, but I think English speakers, mistakenly assuming it to be French, might say sy-NAFF. (Pro tip: If a word contains ph and doesn‚Äôt split it across two syllables, you can almost wager money that it came from Greek. Also, pronouncing a foreign word using the wrong language‚Äôs orthography is a great way to make a linguistics nerd‚Äôs blood boil. And just to prove that I‚Äôm a linguistics nerd, orthography is derived from ŒøœÅŒ∏Œø- (ortho-, correct) and -Œ≥œÅŒ±œÜŒØ·æ± (-graph√≠ƒÅ, writing).)

Ionian and pentatonic have similar structures and share five notes‚Ä¶ but for the purposes of this analysis, that‚Äôs almost where their similarities stop.

Ionian interval spacing (circle of fifths order)
#Mode1 234567Intervals
4Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1 1 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω
1Ionian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω
5MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1
2Dorian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω 1
6Aeolian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1
3Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω 1 1
7Locrian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 11

I‚Äôve analyzed Ionian‚Äôs tetrachord as whole tone, whole tone, semitone, placing the synaphe mid-scale. Swapping the synaphe with the tetrachord above it shifts the scale down, note by note. (Remember, a scale is a repeating note pattern, so in Mixolydian, ‚Äúthe tetrachord above it‚Äù is notes 1-3, and it‚Äôs split across the start and end of the scale in Aeolian and Locrian.) Only Lydian‚Äôs interval list is more front-loaded than Ionian‚Äôs ‚Äì it swaps Ionian‚Äôs first semitone with the following whole tone, with the following results:

  • Lydian‚Äôs fourth note is the only sharp in the entire table.
  • Each mode after Ionian adds flats to its notes, one by one.
  • Locrian‚Äôs first and fourth notes are the only ones that aren‚Äôt lowered from their positions in Ionian.

Note also the following patterns within each mode:

  • The note it lowers is either five semitones above or seven below the one its predecessor lowered.
  • Its sole tritone consists of the note it lowers and the note its successor lowers.
Pentatonic interval spacing (circle of fourths order)
#Mode1 2345Intervals
3Naigyrhp Blues Minor C‚ôÆD‚ôØ F‚ôÆ G‚ôØA‚ôØ 1¬Ω11¬Ω 11
5Nailoea Minor 5t C‚ôÆD‚ôØF‚ôÆ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ 1¬Ω111¬Ω 1
2Nairod Neutral 5t C‚ôÆD‚ôÆF‚ôÆ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ11¬Ω11¬Ω 1
4NaidyloximScottish 5tC‚ôÆD‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ11¬Ω111¬Ω
1Nainoi Major 5t C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ111¬Ω11¬Ω

I‚Äôve analyzed pentatonic‚Äôs trichord as whole tone, minor third, placing the synaphe at the start of the scale. As it happens, pentatonic major‚Äôs intervals are as back-loaded as possible: that is, every other C-rooted mode of the pentatonic scale moves at least one note up a semitone. If we want to lower any notes besides the root, we have to lower the root before them.

Thus, while Ionian is second in its circle of fifths order, major pentatonic closes out its own circle of fourths. The next transposition in this sequence will yield C‚ô≠ blues minor (or B blues minor, whichever you prefer).

A few additional observations regarding both tables:

  • C Dorian, C Aeolian, and C Phrygian all contain C, D‚ôØ, F, G, A‚ôØ (enharmonically, as C, E‚ô≠, F, G, B‚ô≠).
  • Ionian‚Äôs final semitone is why C Locrian and C Phrygian use D‚ô≠. That semitone doesn‚Äôt exist in pentatonic.
  • Shifting major pentatonic‚Äôs intervals one space to the right instead changes D to D‚ôØ, E to F, and A to A‚ôØ.
  • As a result, the scales have effectively opposite directions of motion.

One final note: I highlighted the extra whole step, but its different position in each scale isn‚Äôt, in and of itself, why they move in different directions. In fact, since both scales are mostly made of whole steps, multiple intervals could be considered their synaphai; the choice depends entirely on the arbitrary choice of trichord or tetrachord pattern. Two such patterns can fit for the pentatonic scale and three for Ionian; each result in different synaphai and n-chord divisions. I used my divisions because the others split one of the base scale‚Äôs n-chords. (I‚Äôve highlighted my approaches below.)

Ionian tetrachords & pentatonic trichords & synaphai, oh my
Scale Pattern n-chord 1 n-chord 2 Synaphe
Major 5t 11¬Ω 23 45 1
Major 5t 1¬Ω1 34 51 2
Ionian 11¬Ω 567 123 4
Ionian 1¬Ω1 671 234 5
Ionian ¬Ω11 712 345 6

Note that the Ancient Greeks used the final analysis for their diatonic genus, which was nearly identical to our Ionian scale in all but name. When in Greece, I shall do as the Greeks did, but in this section, I figured it was better to defer the added complexity until this part of my explanation.

In short, the extra whole step‚Äôs position per se doesn‚Äôt affect the scale‚Äôs direction; they move in different directions mostly because Ionian‚Äôs last interval is a semitone and major pentatonic‚Äôs is a minor third. However, as we‚Äôre about to see, the circle orders wouldn‚Äôt exist even without the pentatonic and Ionian scales‚Äô atypically regular note spacing. Transforming one mode of most other scales into another requires far more work.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

An Analysis of Five-Semitone Scale Rotation

Ultimately, the pentatonic and Ionian scales are, respectively, the only pentatonic and heptatonic scales in 12-TET for which moving a single note by a semitone amounts to a scale rotation. There‚Äôs a relatively simple mathematical explanation for why, too:

  • Both scales are primarily composed of two identical interval collections, summing to five semitones each.
    Ionian & Pentatonic Building Blocks
    Scalen-chordNotesIntervalsOutlier
    IonianTetrachord43Semitone
    PentatonicTrichord32Minor third
  • A synaphe (additional whole tone) separates the two n-chords.
  • All but one of the n-chord‚Äôs intervals are whole tones. The outlier differs in size by a semitone.
  • Rotating the scale by n degrees swaps the n-chord and the synaphe.
  • This has a single effect on the interval composition: a whole tone swaps positions with an outlier.
  • Since the outlier differs by merely a semitone, the sole result on the scale‚Äôs harmonic composition is to move a single note by a semitone:
    Outcome of swapping n-chord with synaphe
    OutlierOutlier movesNote moves
    Minor thirdDownUp
    SemitoneDownDown
    Minor thirdUpDown
    SemitoneUpUp
  • This is why the pattern depends on the notes being almost, but not quite, completely evenly distributed: rotating a less even distribution moves more notes; rotating a completely even distribution moves none.
  • It‚Äôs also why the pattern is so closely linked to the circles of fourths and fifths: swapping the synaphe with the n-chord requires rotating the scale by either five or seven semitones.
  • Five and seven are the magic numbers because 12 modulo 7 = 5. In other words, after a note has moved seven semitones, five semitones of the octave remain.
  • For a concrete examination, let‚Äôs look again at Ionian (1, 1, ¬Ω, 1, 1, 1, ¬Ω) and Mixolydian (1, 1, ¬Ω, 1, 1, ¬Ω, 1).
    • Changing Ionian to Mixolydian causes a single change: intervals 6 and 7 swap places.
    • Ionian‚Äôs first three intervals are identical to its last three.
    • Mixolydian‚Äôs first three intervals are identical to its fourth through sixth.
    • Ionian‚Äôs first three intervals are identical to Mixolydian‚Äôs.
    • Ionian‚Äôs fifth through seventh intervals are identical to Mixolydian‚Äôs fourth through sixth.
    • Ionian‚Äôs fourth and fifth intervals are also identical to Mixolydian‚Äôs fourth and fifth.
    • Ionian‚Äôs fourth interval is identical to Mixolydian‚Äôs seventh.
    • Ionian‚Äôs sixth interval is a semitone larger than Mixolydian‚Äôs.
    • Mixolydian‚Äôs seventh interval is a semitone larger than Ionian‚Äôs.
    If any of this weren‚Äôt true, swapping those two intervals wouldn‚Äôt rotate the scale by five semitones.
  • Rotating a scale with less uniform interval spacing changes its interval composition substantially more.
  • Rotating a scale with completely uniform intervals does not change its interval composition at all ‚Äì thus, a completely uniform scale has only a single mode.

In summary, for moving a single note of any five- or seven-note scale in 12-TET by a semitone to rotate the scale, its intervals must be almost completely uniform, with only two identical outliers that:

  1. Differ in size from the remainder by only a semitone
  2. Are separated by five semitones

One final question may remain for readers: why is the number of outliers so important? Actually, it isn‚Äôt; it‚Äôs just important that the outliers be identical. If a seven-note scale could be completely uniform apart from one outlier, moving that interval would also rotate the scale. However, it can‚Äôt: 12 modulo 7 is 5, and in turn, 7 modulo 5 is 2. That is, five extra semitones must be distributed across seven notes; thus, two intervals must be outliers.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Other Single-Note Scale Rotations

I‚Äôve focused most of my analysis so far on pentatonic and heptatonic scales, but now that I better understand the mathematical principles explaining why this happens, I‚Äôve expanded my scope somewhat to see if I can uncover other examples of similar patterns with scale rotations of various interval sizes. I‚Äôve uncovered a few, which I‚Äôll explain in a moment.

Other equal temperaments certainly have similar examples (for instance, in 24-TET, rotation by 11 or 13 quarter-tones should produce similar results for similar 11- and 13-note scales), but I haven‚Äôt finished developing tools for scale analysis outside 12-TET, so they will have to wait.

Do other scales exist in 12-TET that don‚Äôt contain the above composition for which moving a single note by a semitone will qualify as a scale rotation? As it happens, yes: I can say with complete confidence, without even having to think about it, that the hendecatonic scale must demonstrate the same principle. And I say the hendecatonic scale for a simple reason: 12-TET contains only a single hendecatonic scale. The reason may be self-explanatory, but if it isn‚Äôt, I‚Äôll give you a hint: It‚Äôs also why it contains only a single dodecatonic scale.

In 12-TET, hendecatonic scales must contain all but one note of the chromatic scale. Thus, it must contain ten semitones and one whole tone, and swapping its whole tone with any of its semitones qualifies as a scale rotation by default. There are only eleven ways to remove notes that aren‚Äôt the root; thus, a single scale with eleven modes, and it displays similar patterns not just for the circle of fifths but for every possible interval in 12-TET.

Of course, the very fact that only one hendecatonic scale exists in 12-TET somehow makes this feel vastly less impressive, even though it has exactly the same cause as Ionian‚Äôs circle of fifths pattern. Funny how that works.

Applying this same principle, we can determine that one other heptatonic scale exists in 12-TET for which moving a series of single notes by a constant interval size will rotate the scale. However, you don‚Äôt move its notes by a semitone; you move them by a perfect fourth. And, ironically, this doesn‚Äôt rotate it by five semitones; it rotates it by one. And its root won‚Äôt progress through the chromatic scale by semitones: it‚Äôll progress through it by perfect fourths. (This will still take it all the way around the chromatic scale, just in a different order.) It‚Äôs the heptatonic chromatic scale, which has the following interval spacing:

¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 3

Which is to say:

semitone, semitone, semitone, semitone, semitone, semitone, tritone

The notation for this is absolutely cursed, so I won‚Äôt bother displaying charts for its modes. But by following the above explanation, you may be able to understand the inevitable mathematical result of this scale composition.

Similar corollaries apply to some other scale sizes: moving successive notes of the pentatonic chromatic scale (¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 4, or semitone, semitone, semitone, semitone, minor sixth) by seven semitones will inevitably take the scale through all its modes, moving the scale root up by a perfect fifth each time.

However, this only applies to a few scale sizes. Why? To rotate the hexatonic chromatic scale (¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 3¬Ω, or semitone, semitone, semitone, perfect fifth), we must move each scale degree by a tritone. So when we move the root up, we move it a tritone. Two tritones amount to an octave, skipping five-sixths of the chromatic scale.

Each scale‚Äôs only non-semitone interval is (13 - n) semitones, where n is the scale‚Äôs note count. Thus, scale rotation moves notes by (12 - n) semitones. For scale rotation to take us through the entire chromatic scale, this interval cannot be a factor of 12. In fact, in any n-TET, for scale rotations that move single notes by more than a chromatic step to progress through the entire chromatic scale, n modulo the interval size (in units of 1/n octave) must not be 0. Thus, in 12-TET:

  • Scale rotations that move notes by a semitone progress through the entire chromatic scale.
  • Scale rotations that move notes by two semitones (major second) skip half of the chromatic scale.
  • Scale rotations that move notes by three semitones (minor third) skip two-thirds of the chromatic scale.
  • Scale rotations that move notes by four semitones (major third) skip three-quarters of the chromatic scale.
  • Scale rotations that move notes by five semitones (perfect fourth) progress through the entire chromatic scale, raising the root by a perfect fourth across each rotation.
  • Scale rotations that move notes by six semitones (tritone) skip five-sixths of the chromatic scale.

Anything beyond a tritone can be evaluated using the first six parameters: moving a note up by seven semitones equates to moving it down by five. Thus, in 12-TET, the only truncations of the chromatic scale for which this method of scale rotation will work contain 1, 5, 7, and 11 notes, and their rotations will respectively move single notes by a semitone, a perfect fourth, a perfect fourths, and a semitone.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Transformations of the Ionian Scale

Harmonic Minor

Since learning harmonic and melodic minor‚Äôs modes is absolutely essential for anyone who wants to play jazz, I‚Äôve created several sets of tables to help people visualize them better.

Harmonic Minor vs. Modes from Aeolian (rooted on C, in ascending order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
Aeolian ‚ôØ7Harmonic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
AeolianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω11¬Ω11

MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠11¬Ω11¬Ω1

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Thus, as the first set of mode names suggests, harmonic minor‚Äôs modes respectively raise by a half-step:

  • Aeolian‚Äôs seventh degree,
  • Locrian‚Äôs sixth degree,
  • Ionian‚Äôs fifth degree,
  • Dorian‚Äôs fourth degree,
  • Phrygian‚Äôs third degree,
  • Lydian‚Äôs second degree,
  • C-C-C-C-COMBO BREAKER!

Since we‚Äôre transposing every mode to C, we can‚Äôt raise Mixolydian‚Äôs first degree, because it‚Äôs the first degree! Instead, we must lower every other degree by a half-step. Say wha?

Somehow, it‚Äôs actually both even weirder than that, and not weird at all: what we do in the above table is the equivalent of raising the first degree. Since we‚Äôre constraing ourselves to a root of C, raising the first note of a scale by a half-step requires us to lower every note of that scale by a half-step. This results in the first note being the only scale degree we don‚Äôt lower: ¬Ω ‚àí ¬Ω = 0.

In practice, though, it‚Äôs usually already raised for us: it‚Äôs harmonic minor‚Äôs seventh degree! Let‚Äôs see what happens when we root these modes on the corresponding notes of their respective parent C minor scales:

Harmonic Minor vs. Modes from Aeolian (rooted on scale, in ascending order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
Aeolian ‚ôØ7Harmonic minor C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ 1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Aeolian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠ 1¬Ω11¬Ω11
Locrian ‚ôØ6Maqam Tarznauyn D‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆ ¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1
Locrian D‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠C‚ôÆ ¬Ω11¬Ω111
Ionian ‚ôØ5Ionian augmented E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆ 11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Ionian E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆ 11¬Ω111¬Ω
Dorian ‚ôØ4Lydian diminished F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ 1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1
Dorian F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ 1¬Ω111¬Ω1
Phrygian ‚ôØ3Phrygian dominant G‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11
Phrygian G‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆ ¬Ω111¬Ω11
Lydian ‚ôØ2Aeolian harmonic A‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω
Lydian A‚ô≠B‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆ 111¬Ω11¬Ω
Mixolydian ‚ôØ1Super-Locrian ‚ô≠7 B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ ¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω
Mixolydian B‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ 11¬Ω11¬Ω1

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Thus, B‚ô≠ Mixolydian is to C Aeolian as B Mixolydian ‚ôØ1 is to C harmonic minor: each starts from its parent scale‚Äôs seventh note. There‚Äôs actually nothing odd going on here at all; it‚Äôs exactly how modes are supposed to behave. C Mixolydian ‚ôØ1 equates to lowering every note of C Mixolydian except C by a half-step ‚Äì and to raising only the B in B Mixolydian by a half-step.

Observant readers may have noticed that the ‚Äúrooted on C‚Äù¬†table above actually appears to contain several shifts. The missing puzzle piece is that it lists the modes in ascending order rather than ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order, which I did to make the scales‚Äô intervals easier to relate to each other. So let‚Äôs return to ‚Äúcircle of fiths‚Äù order.

Harmonic Minor vs. Modes from Aeolian (rooted on C, in ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
Lydian ‚ôØ2Aeolian harmonicC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω
LydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ111¬Ω11¬Ω
Ionian ‚ôØ5Ionian augmentedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
IonianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω111¬Ω
Mixolydian ‚ôØ1Super-Locrian ‚ô≠7C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ô≠A‚ô≠BùÑ´¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω
MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠11¬Ω11¬Ω1
Dorian ‚ôØ4Lydian diminishedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1
DorianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω111¬Ω1
Aeolian ‚ôØ7Harmonic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
AeolianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω11¬Ω11
Phrygian ‚ôØ3Phrygian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11
PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω111¬Ω11
Locrian ‚ôØ6Maqam TarznauynC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1
LocrianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω11¬Ω111

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

We now see that, broadly speaking, in all except one case, each scale has one fewer sharp or one more flat than its predecessor two entries above. The clear outlier is Mixolydian ‚ôØ1, and this table may further clarify why the mode corresponding to Mixolydian is the one thus affected. Mixolydian corresponds to Ionian‚Äôs fifth scale degree, Dorian‚Äôs fourth scale degree, Phrygian‚Äôs third scale degree‚Ä¶ and that‚Äôs the degree that harmonic minor‚Äôs modes raise. For completeness, here are the modes in ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order, rooted to their respective notes within their parent C minor scales:

Harmonic Minor vs. Modes from Aeolian (rooted on scale, in ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals

Lydian A‚ô≠B‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆ 111¬Ω11¬Ω

Analysis of chord tonality by scale position:

Chord Tonalities by Scale Position & Mode (Harmonic Minor)
ModeIIIIIIIVVVIVII
1Aeolian ‚ôØ7 Harmonic minor mindim AUGmin Maj Majdim
2Locrian ‚ôØ6 Maqam Tarznauyn dim AUGmin Maj Majdimmin

Melodic Minor

Melodic minor is perhaps better related to the modes starting with Ionian. I haven‚Äôt drawn borders this time, because‚Ä¶ well, it‚Äôs probably better to just show the table first.

Melodic Minor vs. Modes from Ionian (rooted on C, in ascending order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
IonianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω111¬Ω
Ionian ‚ô≠3 Dorian ‚ôØ7Melodic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω1111¬Ω
DorianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω111¬Ω1
Dorian ‚ô≠2 Phrygian ‚ôØ6Jazz minor inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω1111¬Ω1
PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω111¬Ω11
Phrygian ‚ô≠1 Lydian ‚ôØ5Lydian augmentedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1111¬Ω1¬Ω
LydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ111¬Ω11¬Ω
Lydian ‚ô≠7 Mixolydian ‚ôØ4Lydian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠111¬Ω1¬Ω1
MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠11¬Ω11¬Ω1
Mixolydian ‚ô≠6 Aeolian ‚ôØ3Aeolian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠11¬Ω1¬Ω11
AeolianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω11¬Ω11
Aeolian ‚ô≠5 Locrian ‚ôØ2Half-diminishedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω111
LocrianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω11¬Ω111
Locrian ‚ô≠4 Ionian ‚ôØ1Super-LocrianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω1111

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

The dual mnemonics for each mode of melodic minor in this table effectively show how we can derive melodic minor and each of its modes in two different ways from two different modes of Ionian:

  1. Melodic minor is Ionian with a flat third or Dorian with a sharp seventh.
  2. Jazz minor inverse is Dorian with a flat second or Phrygian with a sharp sixth.
  3. Lydian augmented is Phrygian with a flat first* or Lydian with a sharp fifth.
  4. Lydian dominant is Lydian with a flat seventh or Mixolydian with a sharp fourth.
  5. Aeolian dominant is Mixolydian with a flat sixth or Aeolian with a sharp third.
  6. Half-diminished is Aeolian with a flat fifth or Locrian with a sharp second.
  7. Super-Locrian is Locrian with a flat fourth or Ionian with a sharp first*.

Asterisks are necessary for the first scale degree when transposing every scale degree to C. When improvising on an existing scale, the same principles apply as with harmonic minor‚Äôs Mixolydian ‚ôØ1 ‚Äì the mode‚Äôs root will already be transposed within the scale you‚Äôre playing, so you just have to bear that in mind when thinking of what notes to play above it. This may be clearer in the following table, which shows how the above modes relate to C melodic minor and C Ionian:

Melodic Minor vs. Modes from Ionian (rooted on scale, in ascending order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
Ionian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 11¬Ω111¬Ω
Ionian ‚ô≠3Melodic minor C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1111¬Ω
Dorian D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ 1¬Ω111¬Ω1
Dorian ‚ô≠2Jazz minor inverse D‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ ¬Ω1111¬Ω1
Phrygian E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆ ¬Ω111¬Ω11
Phrygian ‚ô≠1Lydian augmented E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆ 1111¬Ω1¬Ω
Lydian F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆ 111¬Ω11¬Ω
Lydian ‚ô≠7Lydian dominant F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ 111¬Ω1¬Ω1
Mixolydian G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ 11¬Ω11¬Ω1
Mixolydian ‚ô≠6Aeolian dominant G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆ 11¬Ω1¬Ω11
Aeolian A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆ 1¬Ω11¬Ω11
Aeolian ‚ô≠5Half-diminished A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1¬Ω111
Locrian B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ ¬Ω11¬Ω111
Locrian ‚ô≠4Super-Locrian B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω1111

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

In short, E‚ô≠ Phrygian ‚ô≠1‚Äôs root note is already flat in its parent scale – you don‚Äôt have to flat it again!

‚ÄúCircle of fifths‚Äù order makes it clear that the big note shift from Phrygian to Lydian augmented occurs in the ‚Äúrooted on C‚Äù chart for the same reason the note shift between Mixolydian and Mixolydian ‚ôØ1 occurs with the harmonic minor scale: rooting everything to C means we can‚Äôt lower the first note and must instead raise the other notes by however much we‚Äôd have lowered the first note.

Melodic Minor vs. Modes from Ionian (rooted on C, in ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
LydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ111¬Ω11¬Ω
Lydian ‚ô≠7Lydian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠111¬Ω1¬Ω1
IonianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω111¬Ω
Ionian ‚ô≠3Melodic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω1111¬Ω
MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠11¬Ω11¬Ω1
Mixolydian ‚ô≠6Aeolian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠11¬Ω1¬Ω11
DorianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω111¬Ω1
Dorian ‚ô≠2Jazz minor inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω1111¬Ω1
AeolianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω11¬Ω11
Aeolian ‚ô≠5Half-diminishedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω111
PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω111¬Ω11

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Phrygian mode corresponds to Ionian‚Äôs third degree; that‚Äôs the note melodic minor lowers from Ionian. Thus, Phrygian is the mode that undergoes the note shift in the above table. Moreover, C Lydian augmented raises every note of C Phrygian except its root because its parent scale lowers its corresponding note.

For completeness, here‚Äôs ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order without transposition.

Melodic Minor vs. Modes from Ionian (rooted on scale, in ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
Lydian F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆ 111¬Ω11¬Ω
Lydian ‚ô≠7Lydian dominant F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ 111¬Ω1¬Ω1
Ionian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 11¬Ω111¬Ω
Ionian ‚ô≠3Melodic minor C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1111¬Ω
Mixolydian G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ 11¬Ω11¬Ω1
Mixolydian ‚ô≠6Aeolian dominant G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆ 11¬Ω1¬Ω11
Dorian D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ 1¬Ω111¬Ω1

Of course, as the orange names in the ‚Äúrooted on C‚Äù table suggest, we can also get melodic minor by raising a different set of notes on a different series of modes. I‚Äôve changed the first set of scale names accordingly, and since this interpretation of melodic minor raises pitches from its parent modes instead of lowering them, I‚Äôve printed it first in this table. Note also the Ionian scale‚Äôs different base key here (B‚ô≠ major instead of C major).

Melodic Minor vs. Modes from Dorian (rooted on scale, in ascending order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
Dorian ‚ôØ7Melodic minor C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1111¬Ω
Dorian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1¬Ω111¬Ω1
Phrygian ‚ôØ6Jazz minor inverse D‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ ¬Ω1111¬Ω1
Phrygian D‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠C‚ôÆ ¬Ω111¬Ω11
Lydian ‚ôØ5Lydian augmented E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆ 1111¬Ω1¬Ω
Lydian E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆ 111¬Ω11¬Ω
Mixolydian ‚ôØ4Lydian dominant F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ 111¬Ω1¬Ω1
Mixolydian F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ 11¬Ω11¬Ω1
Aeolian ‚ôØ3Aeolian dominant G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆ 11¬Ω1¬Ω11
Aeolian G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆ 1¬Ω11¬Ω11
Locrian ‚ôØ2Half-diminished A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1¬Ω111
Locrian A‚ôÆB‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆ ¬Ω11¬Ω111
Ionian ‚ôØ1Super-Locrian B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω1111
Ionian B‚ô≠C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ 11¬Ω111¬Ω

Analysis of chord tonality by scale position:

Chord Tonalities by Scale Position & Mode (Melodic Minor)
ModeIIIIIIIVVVIVII
1Ionian ‚ô≠3 Dorian ‚ôØ7 Melodic minorminmin AUG Maj Majdimdim
2Dorian ‚ô≠2 Phrygian ‚ôØ6 Jazz minor inverse min AUG Maj Majdimdimmin
3Phrygian ‚ô≠1 Lydian ‚ôØ5 Lydian augmented AUG Maj Majdimdimminmin
4Lydian ‚ô≠7 Mixolydian ‚ôØ4 Lydian dominant Maj Majdimdimminmin AUG
5Mixolydian ‚ô≠6 Aeolian ‚ôØ3Aeolian dominant Majdimdimmindim AUG Maj
6Aeolian ‚ô≠5 Locrian ‚ôØ2 Half-diminished dimdimminmin AUG Maj Maj
7Locrian ‚ô≠4 Ionian ‚ôØ1 Super-Locrian dimminmin AUG Maj Majmin
