The Ionian Scale‚Äôs Stability

Let‚Äôs use a slightly more flexible root to compare melodic minor‚Äôs modes to Ionian‚Äôs in both directions ‚Äì Ionian‚Äôs modes, melodic minor‚Äôs modes, and Dorian‚Äôs modes. Note especially how much stabler the Ionian scale‚Äôs root is.

Melodic Minor vs. Ionian & Dorian (roots of C¬±¬Ω, circle of fifths order)
Scale 1 234567Intervals
C‚ôØ PhrygianC‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω111¬Ω11
Phrygian ‚ô≠1 Lydian ‚ôØ5Lydian augmentedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1111¬Ω1¬Ω
LydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ111¬Ω11¬Ω
C‚ôØ LocrianC‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω11¬Ω111
Locrian ‚ô≠4 Ionian ‚ôØ1C‚ôØ Super-LocrianC‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω1¬Ω1111
C IonianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω111¬Ω
LydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ111¬Ω11¬Ω
Lydian ‚ô≠7 Mixolydian ‚ôØ4Lydian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠111¬Ω1¬Ω1
MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠11¬Ω11¬Ω1
IonianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω111¬Ω
Ionian ‚ô≠3 Dorian ‚ôØ7Melodic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω1111¬Ω
DorianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω111¬Ω1
MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠11¬Ω11¬Ω1
Mixolydian ‚ô≠6 Aeolian ‚ôØ3Aeolian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠11¬Ω1¬Ω11
AeolianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω11¬Ω11
DorianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω111¬Ω1
Dorian ‚ô≠2 Phrygian ‚ôØ6Jazz minor inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω1111¬Ω1
PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω111¬Ω11
AeolianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω11¬Ω11
Aeolian ‚ô≠5 Locrian ‚ôØ2Half-diminishedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω111
LocrianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω11¬Ω111
PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω111¬Ω11
Phrygian ‚ô≠1 Lydian ‚ôØ5C‚ô≠ Lydian augmentedC‚ô≠D‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1111¬Ω1¬Ω
C‚ô≠ LydianC‚ô≠D‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠111¬Ω11¬Ω
LocrianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω11¬Ω111
Locrian ‚ô≠4 Ionian ‚ôØ1Super-LocrianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω1111
C‚ô≠ IonianC‚ô≠D‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠11¬Ω111¬Ω

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

None of these representations are perfect, but together, they may help illuminate how these scales‚Äô modes are related. As you can see, it‚Äôs quite messy ‚Äì we have to move our root up or down a half-step at points to preserve relationships to the Ionian scale and the circle of fifths. Whether we read melodic minor as Ionian ‚ô≠3 or as Dorian ‚ôØ7, we must move its root three times in a row to keep the circle of fifths progression stable:

  1. Half-diminished to Lydian augmented: lower it a half-step
  2. Lydian augmented to Super-Locrian: raise it a half-step
  3. Super-Locrian to Lydian dominant: lower it a half-step

If the above table continued, its next three modes would be B Lydian, B Lydian dominant, and B Mixolydian ‚Äì and a case could be made for rewriting its last six rows as B‚ôØ Phrygian, B Lydian augmented, B Lydian, B‚ôØ Locrian, B‚ôØ Super-Locrian, and B Ionian.

Harmonic minor‚Äôs modes must shift their root in similar ways to preserve the pattern, except they‚Äôre spaced more unpredictably (which feels inevitable, given that its intervals are also less evenly spaced):

  1. Ionian augmented (#2) to Super-Locrian ‚ô≠7 (#3)
  2. Super-Locrian ‚ô≠7 (#3) to Lydian diminished (#4)
  3. Maqam Tarznauyn (#7) to Aeolian harmonic (#1)
Harmonic minor‚Äôs modes revisited, or, please throw some snacks down this rabbit hole
Scale 1 234567Intervals
Lydian ‚ôØ2Aeolian harmonicC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω
LydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ111¬Ω11¬Ω
Ionian ‚ôØ5Ionian augmentedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
IonianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω111¬Ω
Mixolydian ‚ôØ1Super-Locrian ‚ô≠7C‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω
MixolydianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠11¬Ω11¬Ω1
Dorian ‚ôØ4Lydian diminishedC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1
DorianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω111¬Ω1
Aeolian ‚ôØ7Harmonic minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
AeolianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω11¬Ω11
Phrygian ‚ôØ3Phrygian dominantC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11
PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω111¬Ω11
Locrian ‚ôØ6Maqam TarznauynC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1
LocrianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω11¬Ω111

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

The Ionian scale has a comparatively stable descent: its root only lowers once, in the transition from Locrian to Lydian. As far as I can ascertain, it is the only seven-note scale for which this is true. My hypothesis is that this occurs because it comes as close as any seven-note scale within twelve-tone equal temperament can come to having its notes evenly spaced, without being precisely even. Two whole tones, a semitone, three whole tones, and a semitone.

The Ionian scale‚Äôs descent through its modes‚Äô circle of fifths order requires only a single note change. Other scales‚Äô changes are far less straightforward. Both harmonic and melodic minor‚Äôs equivalent transformations require moving three notes:

Harmonic minor & melodic minor‚Äôs ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù progressions
Scale 1 234567 Shift from Previous Note
C Lydian ‚ôØ2
C Aeolian harmonic
 C‚ôÆ D‚ôØ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ ‚àí¬Ω +¬Ω 0 0 0 ‚àí¬Ω 0
C Ionian ‚ôØ5
C Ionian augmented
 C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ 0 ‚àí¬Ω 0 ‚àí¬Ω +¬Ω 0 0
C‚ôØ Mixolydian ‚ôØ1
C‚ôØ Super-Locrian ‚ô≠7
 C‚ôØ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ô≠ +¬Ω 0 0 ‚àí¬Ω 0 ‚àí¬Ω 0
C Dorian ‚ôØ4

 C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ô≠ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ô≠ ‚àí¬Ω 0 ‚àí¬Ω +¬Ω 0 0 0

Phrygian ‚ô≠1 Lydian ‚ôØ5 Lydian augmented‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ ‚àí¬Ω ‚àí¬Ω 0 0 +¬Ω 0 0

Lydian ‚ô≠7 Mixolydian ‚ôØ4 Lydian dominant‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ô≠ ‚àí¬Ω 0 0 +¬Ω 0 0 ‚àí¬Ω
Ionian ‚ô≠3 Dorian ‚ôØ7 Melodic minor‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ 0 0 ‚àí¬Ω ‚àí¬Ω 0 0 +¬Ω

Phrygian ‚ô≠1 Lydian ‚ôØ5 C‚ô≠ Lydian augmented C‚ô≠ D‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ ‚àí¬Ω ‚àí¬Ω 0 0 +¬Ω 0 0
Locrian ‚ô≠4 Ionian ‚ôØ1 Super-Locrian‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ô≠ G‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ +¬Ω 0 0 ‚àí¬Ω ‚àí¬Ω 0 0

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Note a few additional patterns here:

  • Harmonic minor:
    1. The fourth scale degree changes three times over four consecutive transformations:
      1. C Ionian ‚ôØ5 shifts F‚ôØ to F‚ôÆ. (This is the normal circle of fifths transformation.)
      2. C Dorian ‚ôØ4 shifts F back to F‚ôØ.
      3. C Aeolian ‚ôØ7 changes F‚ôØ once more back to F‚ôÆ.
    2. The seventh scale degree also changes three times over four consecutive transformations:
      1. C‚ôØ Mixolydian ‚ôØ1 shifts B to B‚ô≠. (This is the normal circle of fifths transformation.)
      2. C Dorian ‚ôØ4 shifts B‚ô≠ back to B‚ôÆ.
      3. C Aeolian ‚ôØ7 changes B once more back to F‚ô≠.
    3. Tritonality:
      1. These notes are a tritone apart from each other in the base scale.
      2. The Ionian scale contains only one tritone: F and B.
      3. Harmonic minor contains two: D is also a tritone away from A‚ô≠.
      4. Transforming Ionian to harmonic minor thus requires adding a second tritone.
  • Melodic minor:
    1. The fourth scale degree changes three times over three consecutive transformations:
      1. C‚ôØ Ionian ‚ôØ1 (C‚ôØ Locrian ‚ô≠4) shifts F‚ôØ to F‚ôÆ. (This is the normal circle of fifths transformation.)
      2. C Mixolydian ‚ôØ4 (C Lydian ‚ô≠7) shifts F back to F‚ôØ.
      3. C Dorian ‚ôØ7 (C Ionian ‚ô≠3) changes F‚ôØ once more back to F‚ôÆ.
    2. The seventh scale degree also changes three times over three consecutive transformations:
      1. C‚ôØ Mixolydian ‚ôØ4 (C‚ôØ Lydian ‚ô≠7) shifts B to B‚ô≠. (This is the normal circle of fifths transformation.)
      2. C Dorian ‚ôØ7 (C Ionian ‚ô≠3) shifts B‚ô≠ back to F‚ôÆ.
      3. C Aeolian ‚ôØ3 (C Mixolydian ‚ô≠6) changes F‚ôØ once more back to F‚ôÆ.
    3. Tritonality:
      1. These notes are also a tritone apart from each other in the base scale.
      2. Like harmonic minor, melodic minor has two tritones: E‚ô≠ to A.
      3. Transforming Ionian to melodic minor thus requires adding a second tritone.
  • Melodic minor‚Äôs second set of tritones is exactly a half-step removed from harmonic minor‚Äôs. This is a direct consequence of their mathematical relationships in twelve-tone equal temperament:
    1. C Aeolian is tonally identical to C Dorian ‚ô≠6 (conversely: C Dorian is tonally identical to C Aeolian ‚ôØ6).
    2. C melodic minor is tonally identical to C Dorian ‚ôØ7
    3. C harmonic minor is tonally identical to C Aeolian ‚ôØ7.
    As a direct consequence of the above, the following statements are logically equivalent:
    1. Changing C Dorian (C Aeolian ‚ôØ6) to C Aeolian (C Dorian ‚ô≠6) requires only changing A to A‚ô≠.
    2. Changing C melodic minor to C harmonic minor requires only changing A to A‚ô≠.
    3. Changing C Dorian ‚ôØ7 to C Aeolian ‚ôØ7 requires only changing A to A‚ô≠.
  • The Ionian scale is the only seven-note scale in which only a single note pair makes a tritone. It also has the most uniform note spacing possible for a seven-note scale in 12-TET, as I‚Äôll prove mathematically below.
  • As a mathematical consequence of the following premises:
    1. C Aeolian follows C Dorian in the Ionian scale‚Äôs circle of fifths order.
    2. C melodic minor is C Dorian ‚ôØ7.
    3. C harmonic minor is C Aeolian ‚ôØ7.
    4. Shifting harmonic minor‚Äôs transformed mode up a row (Aeolian to Dorian) gets us melodic minor.
    We can express melodic minor‚Äôs transformations of Ionian‚Äôs modes using:
    1. The mode from one row of harmonic minor‚Äôs transformations of Ionian‚Äôs modes
    2. The key and scale degree shift from the next
    We can thus consider melodic minor a sort of midpoint between two transformations of harmonic minor:
    One weird trick to transform harmonic minor to melodic minor
    Harmonic minor − ½Melodic minorHarmonic minor + ½
    C Lydian ‚ôØ2C Lydian ‚ôØ5C Ionian ‚ôØ5
    C Ionian ‚ôØ5C‚ôØ Ionian ‚ôØ1C‚ôØ Mixolydian ‚ôØ1
    C‚ôØ Mixolydian ‚ôØ1C Mixolydian ‚ôØ4C Dorian ‚ôØ4
    C Dorian ‚ôØ4C Dorian ‚ôØ7C Aeolian ‚ôØ7
    C Aeolian ‚ôØ7C Aeolian ‚ôØ3C Phrygian ‚ôØ3
    C Phrygian ‚ôØ3C Phrygian ‚ôØ6C Locrian ‚ôØ6
    C Locrian ‚ôØ6C Locrian ‚ôØ2C‚ô≠ Lydian ‚ôØ2
    C‚ô≠ Lydian ‚ôØ2C‚ô≠ Lydian ‚ôØ5C‚ô≠ Ionian ‚ôØ5
  • If you‚Äôre starting to suspect that absolutely none of this is coincidental, you‚Äôre right.

(At some point, I plan to make equivalents of ¬ß3‚Äôs charts for at least melodic minor and harmonic minor, and perhaps for some of the Greek scales I discuss below as well‚Ä¶ but not until I‚Äôve written programs to automate their generation, which could take anywhere from a few days to months.)

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Mathematical proof of even spacing

It‚Äôs impossible to distribute a seven-note scale‚Äôs intervals more evenly in 12-TET than Ionian distributes them, and I‚Äôll prove it.

  1. In n-tone equal temperament, for a scale with s notes, divide n by s to determine the mean interval size, expressed in units of 1/n octave (i.e., the smallest possible interval; in 12-TET, a semitone).
    12/7 is 1.714285714‚Ä¶.
  2. If there is a remainder, discard it to get the scale‚Äôs lower interval size, and add one to the result to get its larger interval size. If there is no remainder, skip the rest of this proof; you‚Äôre done (but, as Oliver Messiaen would‚Äôve already told you, you won‚Äôt have any other modes).
    That‚Äôs 1. So all intervals in the scale should be at least a semitone (and, in fact, must be).
  3. Take the modulus of the temperament size and the scale size to determine how many intervals will get an extra 1/n octave added to them.
    12 modulo 7 is 5. Thus, we have five leftover half-steps to add to five of the intervals.
  4. Subtract the number of leftovers from the number of notes in the scale to determine how many intervals don‚Äôt get an extra 1/n octave.
    7 - 5 is 2. Thus, five intervals have added semitones, two don‚Äôt. Five whole steps, two half steps.
  5. To determine the most even interval distribution, first divide the number of occurrences of the more frequent interval by the number of occurrences of the less frequent one.
    • If the divisor is 0, you need to work on your reading comprehension: step 2 already told you to stop.
    • If the less frequent interval occurs multiple times and the quotient is an integer, the scale will repeat the same pattern multiple times per octave and is therefore a mode of limited transposition.
    • If the less frequent interval occurs nearly as often as the more frequent one, you may need to repeat some of these steps, replacing n with the count of the more frequent interval and s with the count of the less frequent one.
    5 / 2 = 2.5. There should be a median of 2.5 occurrences of the more frequent interval in a row.
  6. The interval distribution should take roughly this form: small group of more frequent interval, less frequent interval, large group of more frequent interval, less frequent interval. If there are more than two groups of the less frequent interval, determining the optimal distribution may require repeating some of these steps, replacing with n the more frequent interval‚Äôs count and s with the less frequent one‚Äôs count.
    Since we can‚Äôt have a whole step exactly 2.5 times in a row, we‚Äôll have to have two in one group and three in another. That gives us two whole tones, a semitone, three whole tones, and a semitone. That‚Äôs Ionian. I literally just described the Ionian scale. Median number of whole tones in a row: 2.5. Therefore, its semitones are as evenly spread out as they possibly can be between its whole tones.

Surely that also applies to its complement, right? Let‚Äôs look at the pentatonic scale.

  1. In n-tone equal temperament, for a scale with s notes, divide n by s to determine the mean interval size, expressed in units of 1/n octave (i.e., the smallest possible interval; in 12-TET, a semitone).
    12/5 is 2.4.
  2. If there is a remainder, discard it to get the scale‚Äôs lower interval size, and add one to the result to get its larger interval size. If there is no remainder, skip the rest of this proof; you‚Äôre done (but, as Oliver Messiaen would‚Äôve already told you, you won‚Äôt have any other modes).
    That‚Äôs 2. So all intervals in the scale should be at least a whole tone.
  3. Take the modulus of the temperament size and the scale size to determine how many intervals will get an extra 1/n octave added to them.
    12 modulo 5 is 2. So we have two leftover half-steps to add to two of the intervals.
  4. Subtract the number of leftovers from the number of notes in the scale to determine how many intervals don‚Äôt get an extra 1/n octave.
    5 - 2 is 3. Thus, two intervals have extra semitones, three won‚Äôt. Three whole steps, two minor thirds.
  5. To determine the most even interval distribution, first divide the number of occurrences of the more frequent interval by the number of occurrences of the less frequent one.
    • If the divisor is 0, you need to work on your reading comprehension: step 2 already told you to stop.
    • If the less frequent interval occurs multiple times and the quotient is an integer, the scale will repeat the same pattern multiple times per octave and is therefore a mode of limited transposition.
    • If the less frequent interval occurs nearly as often as the more frequent one, you may need to repeat some of these steps, replacing n with the count of the more frequent interval and s with the count of the less frequent one.
    3 / 2 = 1.5. There should be a median of 1.5 occurrences of the more frequent interval in a row.
  6. The interval distribution should take roughly this form: small group of more frequent interval, less frequent interval, large group of more frequent interval, less frequent interval. If there are more than two groups of the less frequent interval, determining the optimal distribution may require repeating some of these steps, replacing with n the more frequent interval‚Äôs count and s with the less frequent one‚Äôs count.
    Since we can‚Äôt have exactly 1.5 whole steps in a row, we‚Äôll have to have two in one group and one by itself. That gives us two whole tones, a minor third, a whole tone, and a minor third. Which, again, is the pentatonic scale.

    7. Of course, we already knew this. If the Ionian scale has the most even interval distribution a heptatonic scale can have in 12-TET, its complement must also have the most even interval distribution a pentatonic scale can have in 12-TET, by definition. Nonetheless, it‚Äôs nice to prove it mathematically.

    Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

    Other single-note transformations of Ionian

    • So far, we‚Äôve almost exclusively explored single-note transformations of Ionian and its modes:
      • Ionian ‚ô≠3 is melodic minor.
      • Ionian ‚ôØ1 is Super-Locrian, melodic minor‚Äôs sixth mode (counting melodic minor itself as the first).
      • Ionian ‚ôØ5 is Ionian augmented, harmonic minor‚Äôs fifth mode.
    • Do other single-note transformations exist? Yes, but fewer than you might expect:
      • Two transformations create other modes of Ionian:
        1. Ionian ‚ôØ4 is Lydian.
        2. Ionian ‚ô≠7 is Mixolydian.
      • Four transformations would create hexatonic scales due to note duplication:
        1. Ionian ‚ô≠1: C‚ô≠ is enharmonically equivalent to B.
        2. Ionian ‚ôØ3: E‚ôØ is enharmonically equivalent to F.
        3. Ionian ‚ô≠4: F‚ô≠ is enharmonically equivalent to E.
        4. Ionian ‚ôØ7: B‚ôØ is enharmonically equivalent to C.
    • Thus, eight single-note transformations create heptatonic scales that aren‚Äôt other modes of Ionian. (I‚Äôve printed the five we haven‚Äôt yet explored in bold, orange text.)
      Threshold of Transformation
      Scale 1 234567 Intervals
      Ionian ‚ôØ1C‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω1¬Ω1111

      Expanding those gives us:
      4. Expand, expand, expand. Clear forest, make land, fresh blood on hands

      Note that Dorian ‚ô≠1 is the mathematical inverse of Dorian ‚ôØ1, as is Dorian ‚ôØ5 of Dorian ‚ô≠4. Dorian ‚ô≠5 is likewise the mathematical inverse of Dorian ‚ôØ4, harmonic minor‚Äôs fourth mode. To clarify:
      6. Guns, sell stocks, sell diamonds, sell rocks, sell water to a fish, sell the time to a clock

      Dorian ‚ô≠5C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1
      Dorian ‚ôØ4C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1
      Aeolian ‚ô≠1C‚ô≠D‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠1¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω
      Mixolydian ‚ôØ1C‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω
      Phrygian ‚ô≠4C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω11
      Ionian ‚ôØ5C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ11¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
      Locrian ‚ô≠7C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠BùÑ´¬Ω11¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω
      Lydian ‚ôØ2C‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω

    Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

    Scale transformations and symmetry

    The above data aren‚Äôt very easy to parse. Clearly, some of these transformations produce more symmetrical and (for lack of a better term) stabler scales than others. The question is, why? I‚Äôm still piecing together the answer, but a piece of the puzzle has to do with note distributions.

    The Ionian scale is internally symmetrical: Dorian mode has the same interval order forwards and backwards. Ionian is tied among heptatonic scales in 12-TET for the smallest number of semitone intervals (only two), and it has fewer tritones than any other heptatonic scale in 12-TET. Also ‚Äì and this is probably the most important fact here ‚Äì Ionian has the most uniform note distribution among heptatonic scales in 12-TET, but ‚Äì and this part is equally important ‚Äì it isn‚Äôt completely uniform. As we‚Äôll see later when we discuss modes of limited transposition, completely uniform scales don‚Äôt even have modes.

    Transforming a single note can thus completely destroy the scale symmetry. As it happens, of all the single-note transformations that produce symmetrical scales, both sets produce versions of the melodic minor scale, which we‚Äôve already examined. Not coincidentally, this also is the closest heptatonic scale within 12-TET to Ionian‚Äôs stability respective to the circle of fifths: while one must transform each note three times for its equivalent of Ionian‚Äôs descent through its modes, at least it‚Äôs the same note three times in a row.

    Another important note is that each transformation of Ionian that raises a note has an equal and opposite transformation that lowers a note and produces the first transformation‚Äôs reflection. For twelve of the fourteen transformations that produce modes of melodic minor, that reflection is another mode of melodic minor; for the remaining two, that reflection is itself, but is applied to a different mode of Ionian:

    • Aeolian ‚ôØ3 produces the same (symmetrical) result as Mixolydian ‚ô≠6.
    • Aeolian ‚ô≠5 produces Locrian ‚ôØ2‚Äôs mirror image. (Or, Mixolydian ‚ôØ4 produces Lydian ‚ô≠7‚Äôs mirror image.)

    Although it‚Äôs pretentious to write Ionian‚Äôs modes this way, we could say the same thing of its own internal transformations:

    • Mixolydian ‚ô≠3 produces the same (symmetrical) result as Aeolian ‚ôØ6, namely, Dorian mode.
    • Aeolian ‚ô≠2 produces Mixolydian ‚ôØ7‚Äôs mirror image. (Or, Locrian ‚ôØ5 produces Lydian ‚ô≠4‚Äôs mirror image.)

Any transformation of the Ionian scale that doesn‚Äôt create a mode of melodic minor, another mode of Ionian, or a hexatonic scale will create a scale with an enantiomorph (Ancient Greek: ·ºêŒΩŒ±ŒΩœÑŒØŒøœÇ, enant√≠os, opposite, + ŒºŒøœÅœÜŒÆ, morphḗ, form) that must appear in a different set of transformations to Ionian. Only scales that do not have internal reflective symmetry have enantiomorphs. This means that:

  • If any mode of a scale has palindromic intervals, that scale does not have enantiomorphs. Aeolian ‚ôØ3 has palindromic intervals and therefore no enantiomorph.
  • If a scale‚Äôs mirror image is one of its own modes, it does not have an an enantiomorph. Ionian is the mirror image of Phrygian. Ionian has no enantiomorph.

In the following table, I‚Äôve taken the liberty of rotating Lydian ‚ôØ5 to the end of the first set of scale comparisons, and Locrian ‚ô≠4 to the start of the second. I had several reasons for this:

  1. This places the symmetrical mode, Aeolian ‚ôØ3 / Mixolydian ‚ô≠6, in the center of the comparisons.
  2. The table‚Äôs other comparisons are between two discrete sets of scale transformations, but here, we compare a set of scale transformations to itself. This places our comparison in sync with itself.
  3. These are the table‚Äôs only comparisons of single-note transformations that can be derived from two discrete parent modes. Oddly, shifting the scales like this actually approximates our usual circle of fifths order:
    • Both sets now open with Ionian ‚ôØ1 / Locrian ‚ô≠4, between which is Lydian.
    • Both sets now close with Lydian ‚ôØ5 / Phrygian ‚ô≠1, between which is Locrian.
  4. Remember in the pentatonic scale analysis how I said symmetrical modes should be circle-order comparisons‚Äô central rows? Now it is.
  5. This results in a few additional quirks:
    1. The 7×7 interval inset has 180¬∞ rotational symmetry.
    2. Both halves also have identical interval distributions, with a pattern that spans across them.

Other one-note transformations don‚Äôt produce symmetrical scales; therefore, they have reflections.

  • Dorian ‚ôØ5 is the reflection of Dorian ‚ô≠4.
  • Dorian ‚ôØ4 is the reflection of Dorian ‚ô≠5.
  • Dorian ‚ôØ1 is the reflection of Dorian ‚ô≠1 (if we disregard transposition of the root).

I specifically used Dorian mode for these examples because it‚Äôs symmetrical in the base scale, but we can still make similar comparisons for the other six modes, since they each have reflections within the Ionian scale:

  • Ionian‚Äôs reflection is Phrygian.
  • Locrian‚Äôs reflection is Lydian.
  • Aeolian‚Äôs reflection is Mixolydian.

Thus, the reflection of a transformation of a non-palindromic mode applies to the parent mode‚Äôs reflection:

  • Aeolian ‚ô≠4 is the reflection of Mixolydian ‚ôØ5.
  • Aeolian ‚ôØ4 is the reflection of Mixolydian ‚ô≠5.
  • Ionian ‚ôØ5 is the reflection of Phrygian ‚ô≠4.
  • Phrygian ‚ôØ4 is the reflection of Ionian ‚ô≠5.
  • Phrygian ‚ôØ3 is the reflection of Ionian ‚ô≠6.

We can observe all this in the table below.

7. Press on the gas, take your foot off the brakes; then run to be the president of the United States
Scale 1 234567 Intervals
Ionian ‚ôØ1 Locrian ‚ô≠4 C‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω1¬Ω1111
Mixolydian ‚ôØ4 Lydian ‚ô≠7 C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠111¬Ω1¬Ω1
Dorian ‚ôØ7 Ionian ‚ô≠3 C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω1111¬Ω
Aeolian ‚ôØ3 Mixolydian ‚ô≠6 C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ô≠11¬Ω1¬Ω11
Phrygian ‚ôØ6 Dorian ‚ô≠2 C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω1111¬Ω1

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

One obvious symmetrical scale isn‚Äôt possible to produce with a single note transformation from the Ionian scale (although it is possible to produce by swapping two intervals; it‚Äôs also equivalent to the whole-tone scale with a note added). Its interval distribution is quite far from uniform, and it‚Äôs also all but impossible to relate to any sort of circle of fifths order. (Also, ‚ÄúNeapolitan major‚Äù and ‚ÄúLydian minor‚Äù are both misnomers. I didn‚Äôt invent them and disclaim all responsibility.)

8. Big smile, mate; big wave, that‚Äôs great; now the truth is overrated; tell lies out the gate

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

I‚Äôm also bizarrely partial to the Major Phyrgian scale, which has its own fearful symmetry, to coin a phrase. It‚Äôs more closely related to the Ancient Greek chromatic genus, which I cover below in the section on Ancient Greek harmony, than it is to the Ionian scale. We‚Äôll therefore revisit it later.

9. Polarise the people; controversy is the game; it don‚Äôt matter if they hate you if they all say your name
Scale 1 234567 Intervals

Ionian augmented ‚ôØ2C‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Modes of Limited Transposition

The scales we‚Äôve examined in detail thus far have as many modes as they have notes. There are seven notes in the scales; multiply this by twelve notes in the chromatic scale and we wind up with a total of eighty-four possible permutations of modes and root notes. However, this is not true of every scale.

French composer Oliver Messiaen coined the term term ‚Äúmodes of limited transposition‚Äù for scales that have fewer modes than notes. Every such scale can be ‚Äúsimplified‚Äù into repetitions smaller than an octave.

  1. A scale with the same number of modes as notes is not a mode of limited transposition.
  2. A scale that can be transposed to a discrete set of notes for every note in the chromatic scale is not a mode of limited transposition.

Messiaen identified seven possible patterns (beyond the chromatic scale in its entirety); there are also numerous ‚Äútruncations‚Äù that remove notes in ways that conform to the patterns.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Mode 1: The Whole-Tone Scale

Since the whole-tone scale repeats a single interval six times (W-W-W-W-W-W), it has only one mode (i.e., itself) that may only be made from two sets of notes:

Whole-tone note sets
# 1 2 3 4 5 6
1 C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ
2 C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ

Multiplying one mode by six repetitions by two note sets gives us a total of twelve transpositions:

Transpositions of the whole-tone scale
TP123456P123456
1 1 C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ 2 C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ
2 1 D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ 2 D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ
3 1 E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ 2 F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ
4 1 F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ 2 G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ
5 1 G‚ôØ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ 2 A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ
6 1 A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ 2 B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ

The whole-tone scale is the first mode of limited transposition, and the only one that has no other modes. (A few truncations of the modes of limited transposition also have no other modes, as we shall see below.)

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Mode 2: The Octatonic Scale

The octatonic scale (H-W-H-W-H-W-H-W), Messiaen‚Äôs second mode of limited transposition, repeats a two-note pattern every three half-steps. Since its pattern has only two notes, it has only two modes:

The second mode‚Äôs modes
# 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8
1 ¬Ω 1 ¬Ω 1 ¬Ω 1 ¬Ω 1
2 1 ¬Ω 1 ¬Ω 1 ¬Ω 1 ¬Ω

And since its pattern spans three half-steps, there are only three possible note sets:

The second mode‚Äôs notes
# 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8
1 C C‚ôØ D‚ôØ E F‚ôØ G A A‚ôØ
2 C‚ôØ D E F G G‚ôØ A‚ôØ B
3 D D‚ôØ F F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A B C

Does it make sense why we have to stop counting here? C octatonic‚Äôs third mode would start on D‚ôØ, but it would contain exactly the same notes as D‚ôØ octatonic‚Äôs first mode, in exactly the same order! We can‚Äôt count them both, so the octatonic scale has six total permutations of modes and note sets.

But if we have to stop counting modes at the end of each cluster, how do we calculate the number of discrete transpositions of the scale and its modes? As far as I can work out, the calculation is quite simple:

  1. (8 / 4 = 2) Divide the scale‚Äôs note count by its repetitions per octave to count its modes.
  2. (2 × 12 = 24) Multiply by the total transpositions (which is always 12 in 12-tone equal temperament).

As we see below, the octatonic scale indeed has twenty-four total transpositions:

Transposing the second mode of limited transposition
M T P 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 M T P 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8
1 1 1 C‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ A‚ôØ 2 1 1 C‚ôØ D‚ôØ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ
2 C‚ôØ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ 2 D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ
3 D‚ôÆ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ 3 D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ
2 1 D‚ôØ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ C‚ôØ 2 1 E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ
2 E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôÆ 2 F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ
3 F‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ D‚ôØ 3 F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ
3 1 F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ E‚ôÆ 3 1 G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ
2 G‚ôÆ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ 2 G‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ
3 G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ F‚ôØ 3 A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ
4 1 A‚ôÆ A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ 4 1 A‚ôØ C‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôØ E‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ
2 A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ G‚ôØ 2 B‚ôÆ C‚ôØ D‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ G‚ôØ A‚ôØ
3 B‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ 3 C‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ D‚ôØ F‚ôÆ F‚ôØ G‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Mode 3: Triple Chromatic

The third mode of limited transposition repeats a three-interval pattern across four half-steps; thus, it has three unique modes that may be constructed from four possible sets of notes, for a total of twelve permutations of notes per four-half-step cluster:

The third mode of limited transposition
M S 1 23456789Intervals
1 1 C‚ôÆD‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆ G‚ôØA‚ôØB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω
2 C‚ôØD‚ôØE‚ôÆ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ F‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôÆ A‚ôØC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØF‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆ
2 1 D‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆ F‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω1 ¬Ω¬Ω1 ¬Ω¬Ω1
2 D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ G‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆ B‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
3 E‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØ C‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆ
4 F‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆ A‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ C‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØ
3 1 D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôØ B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω1¬Ω
2 E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆ G‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ C‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôØ
3 F‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØ A‚ôÆA‚ôØC‚ôÆ C‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆ
4 F‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ A‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôØ D‚ôÆD‚ôØF‚ôÆ

I leave filling in the rest of the table as an exercise for the reader. A quick hint: You should wind up with three sets of twelve scales that each walk up the chromatic scale by half-steps, for a total of thirty-six.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Mode 4: Double Chromatic III

Modes 4 through 7 all repeat patterns of various lengths twice an octave. Since the fourth mode of limited transposition has eight total notes, it has forty-eight possible transpositions.

The fourth mode of limited transposition
M S 1 2345678Intervals
1 1 C‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆF‚ôÆ F‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØB‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
2 C‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØF‚ôØ G‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆG‚ôÆ G‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØC‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆD‚ôÆ
5 E‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØA‚ôÆ A‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØ
6 F‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØE‚ôÆ
2 1 C‚ôÆC‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
2 C‚ôØD‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆD‚ôØF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØE‚ôÆG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØC‚ôØD‚ôÆ

6 F‚ôÆF‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆ
3 1 C‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
2 C‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆ

Mode 5: Tritone Chromatic II

The fifth mode has six notes and repeats twice an octave; therefore, it has thirty-six possible transpositions.

The fifth mode of limited transposition
M S 1 23456Intervals
1 1 C‚ôÆC‚ôØF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆB‚ôÆ ¬Ω2¬Ω ¬Ω2¬Ω
2 C‚ôØD‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØC‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆD‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆC‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØE‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØD‚ôÆ
5 E‚ôÆF‚ôÆA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆD‚ôØ
6 F‚ôÆF‚ôØA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆE‚ôÆ
2 1 C‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØA‚ôØB‚ôÆ 2¬Ω¬Ω2¬Ω¬Ω
2 C‚ôØF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆ

3 D‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ

Mode 6: Whole-Tone Chromatic

Messiaen‚Äôs sixth mode of limited transposition repeats a four-note, six-half-step pattern. Four modes, six note combinations per mode, twenty-four note permutations per cluster, two clusters per octave, forty-eight permutations of roots and modes across the entire chromatic scale.

The sixth mode of limited transposition
M S 1 2345678Intervals
1 1 C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôØB‚ôÆ 11¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω
2 C‚ôØD‚ôØF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôØC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØF‚ôÆG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆ
5 E‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØC‚ôÆD‚ôÆD‚ôØ
6 F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôØE‚ôÆ
2 1 C‚ôÆD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØ 1¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω1
2 C‚ôØD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
4 D‚ôØF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
5 E‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôØC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆ
6 F‚ôÆG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØ
3 1 C‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôØ ¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω11
2 C‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØF‚ôÆG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ

Mode 7: Duplex Genus Secundum Inverse

This decatonic scale repeats the same pattern twice an octave; thus, it has sixty possible transpositions.

The seventh mode of limited transposition
M S 1 2345678910Intervals
1 1 C‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØF‚ôÆ F‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
2 C‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØC‚ôÆ
3 D‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆ G‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôØ
4 D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôØ A‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôÆ
5 E‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ A‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôØ
6 F‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôØ B‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆE‚ôÆ

5 E‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆ A‚ôØC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØ
6 F‚ôÆG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆ
5 1 C‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆ F‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØ ¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1

3 D‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
4 D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆ A‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
5 E‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆ
6 F‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆ B‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØ

Truncations & Implications

  • Two examples of truncations of Messaien‚Äôs modes are the diminished seventh chord, which removes every other note from the octatonic scale (mode 2):
    Transposing the diminished seventh chord
    P/T 1 2 3 4 P/T 1 2 3 4 P/T 1 2 3 4 P/T 1 2 3 4
    A/1 C‚ôÆ D‚ôØ F‚ôØ A‚ôÆ B/1 D‚ôØ F‚ôØ A‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ C/1 F‚ôØ A‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôØ D/1 A‚ôÆ C‚ôÆ D‚ôØ F‚ôØ
    A/2 C‚ôØ E‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôØ B/2 E‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ A‚ôØ C‚ôØ C/2 G‚ôÆ A‚ôØ C‚ôØ E‚ôÆ D/2 A‚ôØ C‚ôØ E‚ôÆ G‚ôÆ
    A/3 D‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôØ B‚ôÆ B/3 F‚ôÆ G‚ôØ B‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ C/3 G‚ôØ B‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ D/3 B‚ôÆ D‚ôÆ F‚ôÆ G‚ôØ
    And the augmented chord, which removes every other note from the whole-tone scale (mode 1):
    Transposing the augmented chord
    P/T 1 2 3 P/T 1 2 3 P/T 1 2 3 P/T 1 2 3
    A/1 C‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ G‚ôØ A/2 C‚ôØ F‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ A/3 D‚ôÆ F‚ôØ A‚ôØ A/4 D‚ôØ G‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ
    B/1 E‚ôÆ G‚ôØ C‚ôÆ B/2 F‚ôÆ A‚ôÆ C‚ôØ B/3 F‚ôØ A‚ôØ D‚ôÆ B/4 G‚ôÆ B‚ôÆ D‚ôØ
    C/1 G‚ôØ C‚ôÆ E‚ôÆ C/2 A‚ôÆ C‚ôØ F‚ôÆ C/3 A‚ôØ D‚ôÆ F‚ôØ C/4 B‚ôÆ D‚ôØ G‚ôÆ

    (Note: Each arrangement of the three diminished seventh chords appears on the same line as its rotations; by contrast, the augmented chord‚Äôs three-note sets are 3×3 squares. For each chord, A/2 precedes B/1.)

    Since both chords truncate their parent modes in ways that maintain their symmetry, they both have only twelve transpositions. Put another way, each inversion of a diminished seventh chord or an augmented chord contains the same notes as its parent. We can contrast this with major and minor chords, which each have first and second inversions and therefore have thirty-six transpositions across the chromatic scale.
  • Messaien omitted several scales on the grounds that they simply truncated scales he‚Äôd already listed, but he arguably applied this principle rather arbitrarily: every scale in his list is a truncation of either mode 7 or mode 3 (or, frequently, of both). Since modes 1 & 2 repeat more often, there‚Äôs arguably a stronger case for treating them differently; however, modes 4–6 don‚Äôt.
  • The Ionian scale, W-W-H-W-W-W-H, forms a useful contrast with modes of limitated transposition: the extra W between the W-W-H patterns makes it impossible to simplify into a smaller pattern. It therefore has seven modes, which each have twelve variants, for a total of eighty-four permutations.
  • An important consequence of modes of limited transposition in music theory: their tonalities are ambiguous, since multiple keys could be the root. In many cases, these notes are a tritone apart, which can provide interesting opportunities for tritone substitutions, but it also provides challenges that are absent when writing for less ambiguous tonalities such as the Ionian scale.
  • Modes of limited transposition never have fewer than twelve permutations in twelve-tone equal temperament, since even scales with only one mode can still start on all twelve notes of the chromatic scale.
  • This is a complete list of every set of notes in 12-TET temperament with only a single mode:
    • The chromatic scale
    • The whole-tone scale
    • The diminished seventh chord
    • The augmented chord
    • The tritone
    • The octave
    It is no coincidence that every single one of these intervals, expressed in semitones, divides evenly into 12.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Mode 0: The Chromatic Scale

  • The chromatic scale itself merits further discussion. As it repeats one interval twelve times (H-H-H-H-H-H-H-H-H-H-H-H), it has only one mode which in turn may only be made from one permutation of notes. The chromatic scale can therefore be transposed in twelve different ways across the entire, um, chromatic scale:
    Permuatations of the Chromatic Scale
    #123456789101112
    1C‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ
    2C‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ
    3D‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØ
    4D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆ
    5E‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØ
    6F‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆ
    7F‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ
    8G‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØ
    9G‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆ
    10A‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØ
    11A‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆ
    12B‚ôÆC‚ôÆC‚ôØD‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆA‚ôØ
    By extension, we might consider the chromatic scale the Zeroth Mode of Limited Transposition: all other scales in twelve-tone equal temperament are truncations of it.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Microtonal corollaries

  • In any t-tone equal temperament with t > 12 and t modulo 12 = 0, i.e.:
    • t = 12 × n
    • n is an integer
    • n > 1
    The 12-tone chromatic scale is a mode of limited transposition. Since it never has more than one mode, it always has exactly t possible permutations of modes and root notes. Thus, in 24-tone equal temperament, it has 24 possible permutations of modes and root notes; in 36-TET, it has 36; in 48-TET, it has 48; and so on. Four particular corollaries to modes of limited transposition within 12-TET itself apply:
    The 12-tone chromatic scale as a mode of limited microtonal transposition
    In x-TET:the 12-TCS has x / 12 modes:the same number y has in 12-TET:
    242the whole-tone scale
    363the diminished seventh chord
    484the augmented chord
    726the tritone

    In other words, y consists of evenly spaced intervals whose ratio to 12 equals 12‚Äôs ratio to x.

  • The 12-tone chromatic scale is also a mode of limited transposition in 60-TET, 84-TET, 96-TET, 108-TET, 120-TET, and so on; the analogy just doesn‚Äôt work in those tonalities because 12 doesn‚Äôt have an integer quotient with their ratios to 12 (i.e., 12 / (60 / 12) = 12² / 60 = 2.4, i.e., not an integer).
  • Any scale‚Äôs number of repetitions per octave in any n-TET must be an integer factor of n. Thus:
    1. All scales in 12-TET must repeat exactly 12, 6, 4, 3, 2, or 1 times per octave.
    2. Prime equal temperaments (e.g., 13-TET, 17-TET, 19-TET) can‚Äôt have modes of limited transposition.
    3. Nonprime equal temperaments (e.g., 15-TET, 22-TET, 24-TET) must have them.
    Wikipedia‚Äôs article asserts both b and c, without fully explaining them, but the most parsimonious explanation is prime factorization:
    1. Let t-TET exist, where t is composite.
    2. Let f be an integer factor of t.
    3. Therefore, t / f must yield an integer n.
    4. As a result, a scale must exist in t-TET with:
      1. intervals uniformly spaced n notes apart
      2. f repetitions per octave
      3. n discrete transpositions

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

A Crash Course in Ancient Greek Harmony

Etymology

The major scale‚Äôs modes are named for places in or near ancient Greece and/or ancient Greek tribes:

Œë·º± ·ºêœÑ·ø†ŒºŒøŒªŒøŒ≥·øêÃÅŒ±Œπ œÑ·ø∂ŒΩ ·ºëœÄœÑ·æ∞ÃÅ œÑœåŒΩœâŒΩ
(Hai etumologíai tô heptá tónōn)
 [The Seven Modes‚Äô Etymologies]
#Mode Greek Romanized Reference
1Ionian ·º∏œâŒΩŒØŒ± Iōnía region on the western coast of Anatolia (modern Turkey)
2Dorian ŒîœâœÅ·øêŒµœçœÇ Dōrieús one of the four major Hellenic tribes
3Phrygian Œ¶œÅ·ø†Œ≥·øêÃÅ·æ± Phrugíā kingdom in west-central Anatolia
4Lydian Œõ·ø°Œ¥·øêÃÅ·æ± Lūdíā Anatolian kingdom most famously ruled by Croesus
5MixolydianŒºŒπŒæŒø-Œõ·ø°ÃÅŒ¥·øêŒøœÇmixo-Lū́diosliterally ‚Äúmixed Lydian‚Äù
6Aeolian Œë·º∞ŒøŒª·øêÃÅ·æ± Aiolíā region of northwestern Anatolia
7Locrian ŒõŒøŒ∫œÅ·øêÃÅœÇ Lokrís Three separate regions ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locris⟩ of ancient Greece

However, they really don‚Äôt have anything to do with the regions or tribes they were named after, or even the ancient Greek tonoi (singular: tonos) that in many cases shared their names; it was more a case of ‚Äúmedieval Europeans thought it‚Äôd be cool to name their modes after aspects of Ancient Greece.‚Äù

(Tonos comes from the ancient Greek ·ΩÅ œÑœåŒΩŒøœÇ, ho tónos, meaning cord, chord⁽⁵⁾, note, tone, or tension; its dual nominative form was œÑ·Ωº œÑœåŒΩœâ, t·πë tónō, and its plural nominative form was Œø·º± œÑœåŒΩŒøŒπ, hoi tónoi.)

As for the word diatonic, that comes from the Ancient Greek Œ¥ŒπŒ±œÑŒøŒΩŒπŒ∫œåœÇ (diatonikós), literally meaning two tones, in reference to the diatonic tetrachord, which‚Ä¶ well, keep reading.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Ancient Greek Harmony: The Cliffs Notes

This is an oversimplification by necessity, as ancient Greek music theory wasn‚Äôt unified;⁽⁶⁾ Philolaus (Œ¶ŒπŒªœåŒªŒ±ŒøœÇ, Phil√≥laos), Archytas (·ºàœÅœáœçœÑŒ±œÇ), Aristoxenus (·ºàœÅŒπœÉœÑœåŒæŒµŒΩŒøœÇ ·ΩÅ Œ§Œ±œÅŒ±ŒΩœÑ·øñŒΩŒøœÇ, Aristóxenos ho Tarantínos), Ptolemy (Œ†œÑŒøŒªŒµŒºŒ±·øñŒøœÇ, Ptolemaios), and others had quite different conceptions of it. I will list modern sources in an acknowledgement section below.

I should first clarify that very little music of ancient Greece actually survives to this day; the earliest known piece that can reasonably be described as complete is the Seikilos epitaph ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seikilos_epitaph⟩ from the first or second century CE, and while we have an idea what its melody sounded like, how it would have been harmonized is a matter of conjecture. (Older pieces still survive in fragments, such as the Hurrian songs ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurrian_songs⟩, one of which is nearly complete.) Greek authors actually provided fairly complete descriptions of tuning practices, and in at least Archytas‚Äô case, modern scholars believe he was describing the actual practices of his day, but we don‚Äôt really know how Greek music sounded; on some level, we‚Äôre taking the word of contemporary authors, only some of whom seem to have been especially concerned with describing actual musical practice.⁽⁷⁾

I‚Äôll be using numbers to represent the intervals of ancient Greek harmony within 24-tone equal temperament ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarter_tone⟩ (24-TET), which adds an additional 12 notes exactly halfway between each note of the familiar 12-note chromatic scale. In 24-TET, an exact ratio of ²⁴√2:1 determines the spacing of the smallest interval (known as a quarter-tone, downminor second, infra second, or wide unison), thus:

Interval Key
# Interval Tone Exact Approximate
 ¬ºInfra secondQuarter-tone ²⁴√2:1‚âà1.02930223664
 ¬ΩMinor secondSemitone ¬π¬≤‚àö2:1‚âà1.05946309436
1 Major secondWhole tone ‚Å∂‚àö2:1‚âà1.12246204831
1¬Ω Minor third Three semitones ⁴√2:1‚âà1.18920711500
2 Major third Two whole tones ³√2:1‚âà1.25992104989

Note that in scales with only whole-steps and half-steps, I‚Äôll use H (i.e., Half) interchangeably with ¬Ω, and W (i.e., Whole) interchangeably with 1. In all other scales, I‚Äôll only use the numbers.

24-TET is by necessity an oversimplification as well, not least since different authors defined the same interval differently. For instance, here are how Philolaus, Archytas, and 24-TET would define the intervals within a diatonic tetrachord. (A tetrachord is a major element of Greek harmony consisting of four notes.)

Also, I‚Äôve taken the liberty of reversing what they called the first and third intervals ‚Äì ancient Greek harmony defined scales in what we would consider descending order. But then, the ancient Greek metaphor for time literally inverted the modern one: they saw the past as receding away in front of us, continually getting ever more distant, and the future as creeping up from behind us. I actually find their metaphor far more apt than ours: who can actually see the future? And our memories of the past get more distant every day.

I don‚Äôt know if this metaphor affected how they described changes over time. I may be overthinking this, but if they thought of the past as in front of them, they may not have perceived this as a descent. I don‚Äôt have enough information to know if concrete proof exists one way or the other. Certainly, where the ancient Greeks refer to time, translators must be aware of their metaphor, and anyone who reads translated Greek writing that concerns time should take the differences into account (and even ask if the translator knew of them).

Interval Ratios of a Diatonic Tetrachord
Source Low interval Middle interval High interval
Philolaus256 :243‚âà1.05349794239 9:8=1.125 9:8=1.125
Archytas 28 :27 =1.0370370370‚Ä¶ 8:7=1.142857142857‚Ä¶ 9:8=1.125
24-TET ¬π¬≤‚àö2:1 ‚âà1.05946309436‚Å∂‚àö2:1‚âà1.12246204831 ‚Å∂‚àö2:1‚âà1.12246204831

Thus, representing ancient Greek harmony using 24-TET is a substantial oversimplification, and in point of fact, we‚Äôd get closer to Archytas‚Äô definitions in 24-TET by using a quarter tone for the low interval and 1¬º-tone (that is, the interval between a major second and a minor third, known as an infra third or ultra second) for the middle interval. However, the intervals I‚Äôve selected (a minor second and two major seconds) are closer to Philolaus‚Äô definitions and, crucially, can be represented in modern Western music‚Äôs 12-TET.

As one further example, both Philolaus and Archytas define a diatonic tetrachord‚Äôs high and low notes as having 4:3 (1.33333‚Ä¶) ratios, which 24-TET would represent using a perfect fourth (‚âà1.33483985417). Most people‚Äôs ears are insufficiently trained to tell the difference ‚Äì even trained singers with perfect pitch frequently wander off-key by larger differences than that (at least when they‚Äôre not subjected to pitch alteration⁽⁸⁾).

The same ancient Greek tonos could actually use any of three genera (singular: genus). Each tonos contained two tetrachords, four-note sets spanning a 4:3 ratio, or perfect fourth. The note spacing varied between genera, but all three used one interval once per tetrachord and another interval twice, in the following order:

Interval Genera: A Feed from Cloud Mountain
Genus Low intervalMiddle intervalHigh interval
EnharmonicInfra secondInfra second Major third
Chromatic Minor secondMinor second Minor third
Diatonic Minor secondMajor second Major second

The positions of the tetrachords and synaphai, meanwhile, varied between tonoi, with notable consequences:

  • In most tonoi, the synaphe occurred between the tetrachords.
  • In Hypodorian and Mixolydian, it occurred respectively before and after them.
  • Additionally, Lydian, Phrygian, Hypolydian, and Hypophrygian split one tetrachord.

Since tetrachords spanned a 4:3 ratios, the synaphe was mathematically constrained to 9:8, or a major second:

  • 4² × 9 = 144
  • 3² × 8 = 72
  • 144 ÷ 72 = 2

Note that enharmonic has a different meaning in twelve-tone equal temperament than it has in ancient Greek harmony (or any tuning system that uses microtonality). In 12-TET, enharmonic means that two tones have the same pitch. In ancient Greek harmony, it refers to an interval spacing smaller than a semitone and to the tuning system that used this interval. As stated, I‚Äôll be approximating this interval in 24-TET with a quarter-tone.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Ancient Greek Tonoi & Modern Modes

A few notes:

  • As stated above, ancient Greek harmony defined tonoi in descending order; I‚Äôve listed them in our more familiar ascending order to keep them consistent with the other scales on this page.
  • I‚Äôve printed intervals rather than notes because the notation for microtones is extremely confusing if you‚Äôre not already familiar with it. Hopefully, the interval notation will be slightly easier to understand for the enharmonic tonoi. Below this table, I‚Äôll present examples of the chromatic tonoi based on C.
  • A thicker font denotes a larger interval size: 2, 1¬Ω, 1, ¬Ω, ¬º.
  • I‚Äôve placed borders between tetrachords (again, four tonoi split one of their tetrachords) and around the extra whole step (whose background I‚Äôve also highlighted).
  • I‚Äôve printed the modern modes with blue text and brighter borders, with a thicker border below since the next tonos will not be related.
  • I‚Äôve printed the tonoi in the order ancient Greek harmony assigned them: Mixolydian (modern Locrian‚Äôs equivalent) first, Hypodorian (modern Aeolian‚Äôs equivalent) last.
  • Our Dorian, Phrygian, Lydian, and Mixolydian modes don‚Äôt match their eponymous diatonic tonoi. The apparent cause for this is medieval Europeans‚Äô misconception that the ancient Greeks described tonoi in ascending order. (Swiss poet Heinrich Glarean appears to have popularized the error.) I‚Äôll explain this further below.

Here are all three genera of all seven tonoi, followed by the diatonic genus‚Äô modern equivalent:

Approximate Intervals of Ancient Greek Tonoi & Modern Diatonic Modes
Tonos Genus 1‚Äì2 2‚Äì3 3‚Äì4 4‚Äì5 5‚Äì6 6‚Äì7 7‚Äì8
Mixolydian Enharmonic ¬º ¬º 2 ¬º ¬º 2 1
Mixolydian Chromatic ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω  ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1
Mixolydian Diatonic ¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1
Locrian Modern ¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1
Lydian Enharmonic ¬º 2 ¬º ¬º 2 1¬º
Lydian Chromatic ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω  ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω
Lydian Diatonic 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω
Ionian Modern 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω
Phrygian Enharmonic 2 ¬º ¬º 2 1¬º ¬º
Phrygian Chromatic 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω

Dorian Modern 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω 1
Dorian Enharmonic ¬º ¬º 2 1¬º ¬º 2

Mixolydian Modern 1 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1
Hypodorian Enharmonic 1 ¬º ¬º 2 ¬º ¬º 2
Hypodorian Chromatic 1 ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Hypodorian Diatonic 1 ¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1
Aeolian Modern 1 ¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1

The above table is quite abstract, so to follow it up, here are the chromatic tonoi rooted in C and, for the sake of representing what medieval Europeans might have thought they were, their inversions. As in the previous table, I‚Äôve separated the tetrachords in the interval listing to make it clear where they occur, and I‚Äôve highlighted the extra whole-step (a bit more so, even, because it will become a bit less legible shortly).

Greek Chromatic Tonoi & Their Inversions (C roots, linear order)
Chromatic Tonos 1 234567Intervals
Mixolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ AùÑ´ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1
Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω
Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω
Dorian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Hypolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω
Hypophrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypodorian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Mixolydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
Lydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω
Phrygian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Dorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypolydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypophrygian inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ AùÑ´ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω
Hypodorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1

Remember how I said above that Chromatic Dorian was directly relevant to this section? Well, there you go.

(I‚Äôll represent the enharmonic tonoi with similar tables when I figure out how best to do so.)

Scale-based transposition now. My base scales are Chromatic Lydian and Chromatic Hypophrygian inverse; this is an admittedly arbitrary choice that I made purely because they use the fewest accidentals on C. This also creates a neat pattern in the table below:

Greek Chromatic Tonoi & Their Inversions (mode-based roots, linear order)
Chromatic Tonos 1 234567Intervals
Mixolydian B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1
Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω
Phrygian D‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Dorian E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Hypolydian F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Hypophrygian G‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Hypodorian A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ 1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Mixolydian inverse F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆ 11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Lydian inverse E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØ ¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Phrygian inverse D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Dorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Hypolydian inverse B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω
Hypophrygian inverse A‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω
Hypodorian inverse G‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1

The ancient Greek tonoi‚Äôs ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order is:

  1. Hypolydian
  2. Lydian
  3. Hypophrygian
  4. Phrygian
  5. Hypodorian
  6. Dorian
  7. Mixolydian

This may help explain how the Greeks got the names Hypolydian, Hypophrygian, and Hypodorian in the first place: ·ΩëœÄœå (hup√≥) is literally Ancient Greek for under, and remember, the ancient Greeks‚Äô scales went in what we consider descending order.

I‚Äôm reversing the inverted scales‚Äô order in the next table, since as its predecessor clearly demonstrates, they‚Äôre actually moving in the opposite direction from their namesakes. Also, I‚Äôm reintroducing Major Phrygian and its modes here, since they‚Äôre the midway point between the chromatic scales and their inversions.

Greek Chromatic Tonoi & Their Variants (mode-based roots, ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order)
Chromatic Tonos 1 234567Intervals
Hypolydian F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω
Hypophrygian G‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Phrygian D‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Hypodorian A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ 1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Dorian E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Mixolydian B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1
Ultra-Phrygian E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠ ¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
KanakƒÅngi ‚ô≠5 B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω
Hungarian Romani minor F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆ 1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Major Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Hungarian Romani minor inverse G‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1
RasikapriyƒÅ D‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Ionian augmented ‚ôØ2 A‚ô≠B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Mixolydian inverse F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆ 11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Dorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Hypodorian inverse G‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1
Phrygian inverse D‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Hypophrygian inverse A‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω
Lydian inverse E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØ ¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Hypolydian inverse B‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØ ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω

So effectively, Lydian and Hypolydian keep one tetrachord in the same place; the other tetrachord just swaps places with the extra whole-step.⁽⁹⁾ This actually continues to be true throughout the rest of the chromatic scales. Effectively, the extra whole-step either moves three places forward or four places back. Dividing the Ionian scale in this way shows us the same thing occurring with it:

Greek Diatonic Tonoi (C roots, circle of fifths order)
ModernAncient1 234567Intervals
Lydian Hypolydian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1 1 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω
Ionian Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω
MixolydianHypophrygianC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1
Dorian Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω 1
Aeolian Hypodorian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ 1¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1
Phrygian Dorian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω 1 1 1¬Ω 1 1
Locrian Mixolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω 1 1 ¬Ω 1 1 1

Every scale in this table lowers its predecessor‚Äôs extra whole-step to a half-step ‚Äì and because the extra whole-step is always followed by a half-step, that half-step subsequently becomes a whole-step. This is, in fact, exactly the source of most of the patterns we‚Äôve observed throughout our analysis of the Ionian scale. I don‚Äôt know how much the ancient Greeks mapped this out and how much of it simply stemmed from intuition, but if it was by design, the designer was a genius, and I‚Äôm sad that their name has been lost to history.

There‚Äôs no obvious equivalent of the circle of fifths progression for the chromatic genus, though; for reasons explained above, that‚Äôs a special property of the diatonic genus‚Äô mathematical regularity. Rotating most scales requires making more changes to their intervals. Let‚Äôs see the scales on C again, this time with the tetrachord placement standardized around Major Phrygian‚Äôs layout (since it centers the synaphe within the middle row).

Greek Chromatic Tonoi & Their Variants (C roots, ‚Äúcircle of fifths‚Äù order)
Chromatic Tonos 1 234567Intervals
Hypophrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω
Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypodorian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Dorian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Mixolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ AùÑ´ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1
Hypolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω
Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω
Ultra-PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ô≠F‚ô≠G‚ôÆA‚ô≠BùÑ´¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
KanakƒÅngi ‚ô≠5C‚ôÆD‚ô≠EùÑ´F‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ô≠BùÑ´¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω
Hungarian Romani minorC‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠F‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Major PhrygianC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
Hungarian Romani minor inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ô≠¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1
RasikapriyƒÅC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Ionian augmented ‚ôØ2C‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Lydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypolydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω
Mixolydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
Dorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypodorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1
Phrygian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Hypophrygian inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ AùÑ´ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω

It fascinates me how these three sets of modes complement each other. Note the accidental distributions: the inversions have sharps bunched in the middle, the chromatic scales have flats bunched in the middle, and Major Phrygian has flats bunched above it and sharps below it. Of course, the interval distribution explains why that might have happened:

  • The following scales open with minor thirds:
    • The first two chromatic scales
    • Major Phrygian‚Äôs two lowest modes
    • The fourth and fifth inverted chromatic scales
  • The following scales inevitably (we are discussing inversions and reflectively symmetrical scales) close with minor thirds:
    • Major Phrygian‚Äôs two highest modes
    • The last two chromatic inversions
    • The third and fourth chromatic scales

In short, the accidental distribution is a direct consequence of the interval distribution. So let‚Äôs run an experiment. The following table doesn‚Äôt reposition any tetrachords; it just swaps them between scales:

Greek Chromatic Tonoi & Their Variants (C roots, ‚Äúcyclical tetrachord swap‚Äù order)
Chromatic Tonos 1 234567Intervals
Ultra-Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
KanakƒÅngi ‚ô≠5 C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω
Hypodorian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Dorian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Mixolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ AùÑ´ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1
Phrygian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Hypophrygian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ AùÑ´ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω
Lydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypolydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω
Hungarian Romani minor C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω
Major Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω
Hungarian Romani minor inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ôÆB‚ô≠ ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1
Hypolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω
Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω
Hypophrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω
Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω
Mixolydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
Dorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypodorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1
RasikapriyƒÅ C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
Ionian augmented ‚ôØ2 C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω

Neat. Now what if we put the scales back into something resembling linear order?

Greek Chromatic Tonoi & Their Variants (C roots, ‚Äúlinear tetrachord swap‚Äù order)
Chromatic Tonos 1 234567Intervals
Mixolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ AùÑ´ B‚ô≠ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1
Hypophrygian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ AùÑ´ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω
KanakƒÅngi ‚ô≠5 C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω
Dorian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Phrygian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ EùÑ´ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Ultra-Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Hypodorian C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ô≠ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ BùÑ´ 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Hungarian Romani minor inverseC‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ôÆB‚ô≠ ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1
Lydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ôÆB‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω
Hypolydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ A‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω
Major Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypolydian C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω
Lydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ô≠ E‚ô≠ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω
Hungarian Romani minor C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ô≠ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ô≠ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypodorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôÆB‚ô≠ 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1
Ionian augmented ‚ôØ2 C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω
Phrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω
Dorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
RasikapriyƒÅ C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôÆF‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω
Hypophrygian C‚ôÆD‚ôØ E‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ1¬Ω1¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω¬Ω ¬Ω
Mixolydian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôØ F‚ôØ G‚ôÆA‚ôØ B‚ôÆ11¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω 1¬Ω ¬Ω ¬Ω

So, as we can see, each interval‚Äôs relative position has a massive impact on a scale‚Äôs accidental distribution. This makes intuitive sense, but it still might be hard to understand how much it underpins a scale‚Äôs entire composition without seeing it laid out like this.

Let‚Äôs extend the same principle to pentatonic scales, shall we?

Pentatonic Trichorder (I am so, so sorry)
#Mode1 2345Intervals
3Naigyrhp Blues Minor C‚ôÆD‚ôØ F‚ôÆG‚ôØ A‚ôØ 1¬Ω1 1¬Ω11
5Nailoea Minor 5t C‚ôÆD‚ôØ F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØ 1¬Ω11 1¬Ω1
2Nairod Neutral 5tC‚ôÆD‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØ 1 1¬Ω1 1¬Ω1
4NaidyloximScottish 5tC‚ôÆD‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôÆ1 1¬Ω11 1¬Ω
1Nainoi Major 5t C‚ôÆD‚ôÆE‚ôÆ G‚ôÆA‚ôÆ11 1¬Ω1 1¬Ω

Why Our Modes Have Historically Inaccurate Names

Our Ionian mode‚Äôs chromatic counterpart is actually Chromatic Hypolydian, and our Aeolian mode‚Äôs counterpart is Chromatic Hypodorian. Why is that? Well, as I remarked above, medieval Europeans were confused. Four of our modern modes also had multiple names, three of which they borrowed from the Ancient Greek tonoi: their Hypodorian was our Aeolian, their Hypophrygian was our Locrian, and their Hypolydian was our Ionian. So, if we plug in those names and recenter the order around our Aeolian mode:

A Great Mode Discombobulation
AncientMedievalModern
Dorian Phrygian Phrygian
Hypolydian Lydian Lydian
HypophrygianMixolydian Mixolydian
Hypodorian Hypodorian Aeolian
Mixolydian HypophrygianLocrian
Lydian Hypolydian Ionian
Phrygian Dorian Dorian

Visualizing the mistake they made becomes easier. In short, their misconception that Greek harmony went in ascending order led them to reverse the mode order. Since Ionian has an odd number of notes, it also has an odd number of modes. Its inversion is also one of its own modes ‚Äì which, to be clear, is not a given (for instance, it‚Äôs not true of the Greeks‚Äô chromatic tonoi, which is why I listed their inversions separately above). For this to hold, one of the scale‚Äôs modes must be symmetrical ‚Äì in this case, our Dorian mode:

Inverting the Ionian Scale
ModernAncientModeModernAncientInversion
Aeolian Hypodorian W H W W H W WMixolydianHypophrygianW W H W W H W
Locrian Mixolydian H W W H W W WLydian Hypolydian W W W H W W H
Ionian Lydian W W H W W W HPhrygian Dorian H W W W H W W
Dorian Phrygian W H W W W H WDorian Phrygian W H W W W H W
Phrygian Dorian H W W W H W WIonian Lydian W W H W W W H
Lydian Hypolydian W W W H W W HLocrian Mixolydian H W W H W W W
MixolydianHypophrygianW W H W W H WAeolian Hypodorian W H W W H W W

Thus, by necessity, they were still going to get one right; it just happened to be our Aeolian mode. Why wasn‚Äôt it our Dorian mode? Apparently, they made an off-by-one error in assuming the Greeks listed the tonoi themselves in ascending order as well. Let‚Äôs move the tonoi on the right down by one and plug in their medieval names:

A Medieval Off-by-One Error
MedievalAncientModeMedievalAncientInversion ‚àí 1
Hypodorian Hypodorian W H W W H W WHypodorian Hypodorian W H W W H W W
HypophrygianMixolydian H W W H W W WMixolydian HypophrygianW W H W W H W
Hypolydian Lydian W W H W W W HLydian Hypolydian W W W H W W H
Dorian Phrygian W H W W W H WPhrygian Dorian H W W W H W W
Phrygian Dorian H W W W H W WDorian Phrygian W H W W W H W
Lydian Hypolydian W W W H W W HHypolydian Lydian W W H W W W H
Mixolydian HypophrygianW W H W W H WHypophrygianMixolydian H W W H W W W

Now the ancient names on the left line up with the medieval names on the right, and vice versa.

Remember, the ancient Greeks used the opposite metaphor for time from the modern one: they thought of the past as being in front and the future as being behind them. I don‚Äôt know if this was the source of medieval Europeans‚Äô confusion, but it wouldn‚Äôt entirely surprise me if it was.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Applied Greek Harmony: Tetrachords in Modern Scales

We‚Äôve already seen how the Ionian scale is a variant of a scale in which a tetrachord is repeated with a whole-tone separation (though in our Ionian mode, specifically, the second tetrachord is split midway through). To reiterate, let‚Äôs look at D Dorian, whose intervals are W-H-W-W-W-H-W:

  • It opens with a W-H-W tetrachord (i.e., D, E, F, G).
  • It features another whole step (i.e., G, A).
  • It closes by repeating the W-H-W tetrachord (i.e., A, B, C, D).

And because the tetrachord itself is symmetrical, so is Dorian mode itself.

A few scales in Other Scales and Tonalities above are also built on two tetrachords separated by a whole step:

  • Chromatic Dorian (¬Ω, ¬Ω, 1¬Ω, 1, ¬Ω, ¬Ω, 1¬Ω) and its modes literally are an ancient Greek genus.
  • Chromatic Dorian inverse (1¬Ω, ¬Ω, ¬Ω, 1, 1¬Ω, ¬Ω, ¬Ω) and its modes also qualify.
  • Major Phrygian (¬Ω, 1¬Ω, ¬Ω, 1, ¬Ω, 1¬Ω, ¬Ω) uses a ¬Ω‚Äì1¬Ω‚Äì¬Ω tetrachord, a whole step, and another ¬Ω‚Äì1¬Ω‚Äì¬Ω tetrachord. It also has the same reflective symmetry as our Dorian mode: since its repeated tetrachord is symmetrical and its extra whole-step occurs between them, it too is symmetrical.

Scales built on two tetrachords can be pleasing in their regularity, and they may be helpful starting places when you first write pieces that stray from the Ionian scale‚Äôs familiarity. Symmetrical scales built on two of the same tetrachord (e.g., double harmonic minor or modes thereof) may be especially ideal starting places. I‚Äôd suggest inventing your own, but there aren‚Äôt any others.

But you can be creative in varying how the ancient Greeks constructed their harmony. One possibility: a nine-note scale featuring two of the same pentachord (five-note sequence) separated by a whole-step. To fit these criteria, your pentachord must span a perfect fourth (2¬Ω steps), which unfortunately prevents it from being rotationally symmetrical - your options are W-H-H-H, H-W-H-H, H-H-W-H, or H-H-H-W.

If you want rotational symmetry, though, you could invert the second pentachord:

  • W-H-H-H-W-H-H-H-W (Houseini)
  • H-W-H-H-W-H-H-W-H (Genus Chromaticum)
  • H-H-W-H-W-H-W-H-H (Epolygic)
  • H-H-H-W-W-W-H-H-H (Darygic; this one seems especially daring)

The second option, H-W-H-H-W-H-H-W-H, can also be constructed by repeating the same trichord (three-note sequence), H-W, with a half-step separation each time, which is another interesting variation on the ancient Greek idea. Within it, each trichord spans a minor third; the added half-step above it means that the same interval pattern repeats every major third. Above its root key, it also includes a minor third, a major third, a perfect fourth, and a perfect fifth above its root key. These make it potentially a very versatile scale. (Since its dominant chord is diminished and it excludes the major second above its root, it also shares some harmonic characteristics with Phrygian mode and Phrygian dominant.) But these aren‚Äôt the only possible variants – be creative!

Then again, you may prefer harmonic minor or melodic minor, which respectively only lower one note of Aeolian mode and raise one note of Ionian mode; both are also so ubiquitous in Western music that they may be intuitive. Neither, however, possess the repeated tetrachord of the ancient Greek genera. (Melodic minor does possess a symmetrical mode, Aeolian dominant [W-W-H-W-H-W-W]; harmonic minor does not.)

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Acknowledgements & Sources

I first wish to thank Marty O‚ÄôDonnell (yes, that Marty O‚ÄôDonnell) for pointing out that it wasn‚Äôt sufficiently clear what parts of this section I was oversimplifying; his feedback resulted in a much clearer explanation. However, the opinions presented in this section are entirely my own. In particular, Marty believes modern scholars have extrapolated more from ancient Greek texts than is merited by their contents – and in the interest of fairness, I must point out that he has a degree in music theory, and I don‚Äôt. However, I must also be fair to myself: Marty got his degree decades ago, and a lot of music scholarship has been done since then.

But even then, I‚Äôll be the first person to admit that I‚Äôm by no means an infallible source, so here are some starting places for readers wishing to learn more about this subject. Wi­ki­pe­dia ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_system_of_ancient_Greece⟩ has much, much more information ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Octave_species⟩; the Xenharmonic wiki ⟨en.xen.wiki/w24edo_scales⟩, Feel Your Sound ⟨feelyoursound.com/scale-chords⟩, Midicode ⟨web.archive.org/web/20120308164408/www.midicode.com/tunings/greek.shtml⟩, and Ian Ring‚Äôs Scale Finder were also helpful. (The latter is so incredibly helpful that I‚Äôve begun linking to its entries for scales on this page.) Solra Bizna and I also wrote a Rust program to automate several aspects of scale analysis; some of its output is on this very page.

I consulted several other resources researching this section; many were too technical to be of interest to non-specialists, but those seeking more detailed technical analysis of ancient Greek tuning systems may be interested in Robert Erickson‚Äôs analysis of Archytas ⟨ex-tempore.org/ARCHYTAS/ARCHYTAS.html⟩ (who provided what modern scholars believe to be detailed, accurate descriptions of his era‚Äôs actual tuning practices). Our knowledge of Archytas‚Äô musical writings evidently comes from Ptolemy‚Äôs Harmonics, whose author comments in depth on the former‚Äôs writings⁽⁷⁾; large fragments of Aristoxenus‚Äô Elements of Harmony and smaller fragments of Philolaus‚Äô musical writings survive to this day.

But I think it‚Äôs most helpful to quote the ancient Greeks in their own words (or as close to their words as English speakers without educations in Attic Greek will understand), so here, via Cris Forester‚Äôs book on the subject ⟨chrysalis-foundation.org/musical-mathematics-pages/philolaus-and-euclid⟩, is a translated excerpt of Philolaus, whom I quote less for his comprehensibility than for his technical detail:

The magnitude of harmonia is syllaba and di‚Äôoxeian. The di‚Äôoxeian is greater than the syllaba in epogdoic ratio. From hypate [E] to mese [A] is a syllaba, from mese [A] to neate [or nete, E¹] is a di‚Äôoxeian, from neate [E¹] to trite [later paramese, B] is a syllaba, and from trite [B] to hypate [E] is a di‚Äôoxeian. The interval between trite [B] and mese [A] is epogdoic [9:8], the syllaba is epitritic [4:3], the di‚Äôoxeian hemiolic [3:2], and the dia pason is duple [2:1]. Thus harmonia consists of five epogdoics and two dieses; di‚Äôoxeian is three epogdoics and a diesis, and syllaba is two epogdoics and a diesis.
—Philolaus, translated by Andrew Barker, Greek Musical Writings, Vol. 2 (1989:
—Cambridge University Press).
—[Text and ratios in brackets are Cris Forester‚Äôs.]

Difficult as this is to parse, a close reading reveals Philolaus to be describing the Ionian scale:

  • 3:2 is 1.5; our perfect fifth rounds to 1.49830707688.
  • 4:3 is 1.333‚Ä¶; our perfect fourth rounds to 1.33483985417.
  • 9:8 is 1.125; our whole step rounds to 1.12246204831.
  • Philolaus‚Äô dieses are therefore 256:243, or 1.05349794239; our half step rounds to 1.05946309436.

In other words:

  • A dia pason (or harmonia) is exactly an octave.
  • A di‚Äôoxean is almost exactly a perfect fifth.
  • A syllaba is almost exactly a perfect fourth.
  • An epogdoic is almost exactly a whole step.
  • A diesis is almost exactly a half-step.

Plugging those in gives us:

The magnitude of an octave is a perfect fourth and a perfect fifth. The perfect fifth is greater than the perfect fourth in whole-step ratio. From hypate [E] to mese [A] is a perfect fourth, from mese [A] to neate [or nete, E¹] is a perfect fifth, from neate [E¹] to trite [later paramese, B] is a perfect fourth, and from trite [B] to hypate [E] is a perfect fifth. The interval between trite [B] and mese [A] is a whole step [9:8], the perfect fourth is epitritic [4:3], the perfect fifth hemiolic [3:2], and the octave is duple [2:1]. Thus an octave consists of five whole steps and two half-steps; a perfect fifth is three whole steps and a half-step, and a perfect fourth is two whole steps and a half-step.

Plus ça change, plus c‚Äôest la m√™me chose.

Philolaus‚Äô description is so exact that I believe we can conclude from it that the ancient Greeks routinely used something very similar to our Ionian scale. However, I must reiterate: ‚Äúancient Greek harmony‚Äù refers to over a millennium of musical practices that were by no means uniform; various authors described other tonoi and indeed entirely different tuning systems. I‚Äôve focused on the tonoi described above for two reasons:

  1. They‚Äôre easy to equate to modern tuning systems.
  2. They clearly inspired (four of) our modern modes‚Äô names.

(Keep an eye on this page ‚Äì I still intend to add more information on the medieval church modes that served as the precursors to our modern modes.)

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Appendix 1: Greek musical terminology

It might seem like overkill to include a table this repetitive, but Google¬†Translate is not great at parsing Ancient Greek. My hope is that this will help.
