‚Ä¶OK, fine, I completely made up the declension of ¬´·øêÃìÃÅŒ¥·øêŒøŒ≥Œª·ø∂œÉœÉ·øê·ø∂ŒΩ¬ª, but to be fair, it wouldn‚Äôt have sufficed at all to have used a modern declension when all the surrounding language is Attic.

(For the time being, a complete explanation of declensions is beyond my scope, but I may eventually find myself unable to resist writing one.)

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Appendix 2: Interval Ratios of 12- and 24-Tone Equal Temperament

As an appendix to the section on tonoi, I‚Äôve also created this table of every possible interval in 24-tone equal temperament. The column ‚ÄúLPT‚Äù means ‚ÄúLowest Possible Temperament‚Äù ‚Äì in other words, to contain an interval, a temperament must be a multiple of its LPT; e.g., if the LPT is 8, the interval will appear in 16-TET, 24-TET, 32-TET, and so on, but will not appear in 12-TET. The lower the LPT, the bolder the font used to print the interval. Intervals printed in blue also appear in 12-TET (our familiar 12-note chromatic scale).

24-Tone Equal Temperament‚Äôs Interval Ratios
#IntervalExactApproximateLPT
1 Quarter tone, infra second 2¹⁄₂₄ =²⁴√2 1.0293022366424
2 Minor second 2²⁄₂₄ = ¹²√2 1.0594630943612
3 Neutral second 2³⁄₂₄ = ⁸√2 1.09050773267 8
4 Major second 2⁴⁄₂₄ = ⁶√2 1.12246204831 6
5 Ultra second, infra third 2⁵⁄₂₄ =²⁴√32 1.1553526968724
6 Minor third 2⁶⁄₂₄ = ⁴√2 1.18920711500 4
7 Neutral third 2⁷⁄₂₄ =²⁴√128 1.2240535433024
8 Major third 2⁸⁄₂₄ = ³√2 1.25992104989 3
9 Ultra third, narrow fourth 2⁹⁄₂₄ = ⁸√8 1.29683955465 8
10Perfect fourth 2¹⁰⁄₂₄= ¹²√32 1.3348398541712
11Wide fourth 2¹¹⁄₂₄ =²⁴√2,048 1.3739536474624
12Tritone 2¹²⁄₂₄ = √2 1.41421356237 2
13Narrow fifth 2¹³⁄₂₄ =²⁴√8,192 1.4556531828424
14Perfect fifth 2¹⁴⁄₂₄= ¹²√128 1.4983070768812
15Wide fifth, infra sixth 2¹⁵⁄₂₄= ⁸√32 1.54221082541 8
16Minor sixth 2¹⁶⁄₂₄= ³√4 1.58740105197 3
17Neutral sixth 2¹⁷⁄₂₄=²⁴√131,072 1.6339154532424
18Major sixth 2¹⁸⁄₂₄= ⁴√8 1.68179283051 4
19Ultra sixth, infra seventh 2¹⁹⁄₂₄=²⁴√524,288 1.7310731220124
20Minor seventh 2²⁰⁄₂₄= ⁶√32 1.78179743628 6
21Neutral seventh 2²¹⁄₂₄ = ⁸√128 1.83400808641 8
22Major seventh 2²²⁄₂₄ = ¹²√2,048 1.8877486253612
23Ultra seventh, narrow octave2²³⁄₂₄ =²⁴√8,388,6081.9430638823124
24Octave 2²⁴⁄₂₄= 2 2 1

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

The Carnatic Numbered Mƒì·∏∑akartƒÅ

A numbered set of fundamental rƒÅgasa (musical scales) that originated in carnatic music (South Indian classical music). They must obey a few rules:

  • They must be samp≈´r·πáa, or complete: i.e., they must contain all seven svaras.
  • The ascending and descending notes must be the same.
  • They must end with the same note they start with. (I have omitted the upper C here for the sake of space.)
  • The third and fifth scale degrees may not be sharp.
  • The fourth and fifth scale degrees may not be flat.

Many of these correspond exactly to frequently used Western scales (e.g., #8 is Phrygian, #20 is Aeolian, #21 is harmonic minor, #22 is Dorian, #23 is melodic minor, #28 is Mixolydian, #29 is Ionian, #65 is Lydian); however, many others are virtually unique to Indian music, and some fundamental modes of Western music (e.g., Locrian mode) are absent here, as they break some of the fundamental rules of mƒì·∏∑akartƒÅ.

Indian music uses multiple scales, and although there are commonly held to be 22 shruti per octave, this remains a matter of some debate, since in practice, pitch tends to vary somewhat. To avoid confusion, I‚Äôm therefore printing the swaras‚Äô Western names.

The Carnatic Numbered Mƒì·∏∑akartƒÅ
#Scale 1 234567Intervals

69DhƒÅthuvardhaniC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ô≠B‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω
70NƒÅsikƒÅbh≈´≈õa·πáiC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ô≠1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω1
71K≈çsalamC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôÆB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω11¬Ω
72RasikapriyƒÅC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôØG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω

The numbering consistently obeys several patterns:

  • Adding 36 to numbers below 36 changes F to F‚ôØ; subtracting 36 from numbers above 36 changes F‚ôØ to F‚ôÆ.

  • The scale number modulo 6 determines the scale‚Äôs fifth, six, and seventh notes:
    1. G, A‚ô≠, BùÑ´
    2. G, A‚ô≠, B‚ô≠
    3. G, A‚ô≠, B
    4. G, A, B‚ô≠
    5. G, A, B
    6. G, A‚ôØ, B
  • The following ranges of numbers open with the following sets of notes:
    Range 1Range 2Notes
    1‚Äì637‚Äì42C, D‚ô≠, EùÑ´
    7-1243‚Äì48C, D‚ô≠, E‚ô≠
    13-1849‚Äì54C, D‚ô≠, E
    19-2455‚Äì60C, D, E‚ô≠
    25-3061‚Äì66C, D, E
    31-3667‚Äì72C, D‚ôØ, E
    This table‚Äôs accidentals correspond exactly to the accidentals of the notes in the ‚Äúmodulo 6‚Äù list.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Yes, but, why?

I gazed into an eldritch dimension by writing a piece in Locrian mode⁽¹⁰⁾. This was the result. I should‚Äôve heeded Nietzsche‚Äôs warning about abysses.⁽¹¹⁾

(More seriously, my use of Locrian mode occasioned a discussion of what musical modes are, which in turn resulted in additional music theory discussion that sent me down a rabbit hole of mathematical patterns. This is probably the HTML equivalent of the bulletin board with string connecting pieces of a conspiracy, except that the conspiracy is ultimately just that music and mathematics are low-key the same thing. If you don‚Äôt believe me, spend enough time studying calculus to understand Euler‚Äôs identity ⟨en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler's_identity⟩ and you‚Äôll see the music in math.)

‚Ä¶and now it‚Äôs ballooned to an even larger size because I simply can‚Äôt leave well enough alone.

If some of the table titles puzzled you, they might‚Äôve been pop culture references you missed:

  • These are just examples; it could also be something much better
    quote from Futurama‚Äôs Twilight Zone parody The Scary Door (S2E3 ‚ÄúA Head in the Polls‚Äù, 1999-12-12)
  • You were expecting modes, but it was me, Dio the circle of fifths!
    take-off on Jojo‚Äôs Bizarre Adventure meme
  • Threshold of Transformation
    song from Isis‚Äô Wavering Radiant (2009-04-21)
  • 4. Expand, expand, expand. Clear forest, make land, fresh blood on hands
    5. Why just shells? Why limit yourself? She sells seashells; sell oil as well⁽¹²⁾
    6. Guns, sell stocks, sell diamonds, sell rocks, sell water to a fish, sell the time to a clock
    7. Press on the gas, take your foot off the brakes; then run to be the president of the United States
    8. Big smile, mate; big wave, that‚Äôs great; now the truth is overrated; tell lies out the gate
    9. Polarise the people; controversy is the game; it don‚Äôt matter if they hate you if they all say your name
    lines from Ren‚Äôs ‚ÄúMoney Game, Pt. 2‚Äù (Demos (Do Not Share), Vol 1, 2020-04-16)
  • Interval Genera: A Feed from Cloud Mountain
    take-off on Between the Buried and Me‚Äôs title ‚ÄúFossil Genera ‚Äì A Feed from Cloud Mountain‚Äù (The Great Misdirect, 2009-10-27)

Normally, I don‚Äôt explain jokes in such an obvious fashion, but I figured this page was already confusing and intimidating enough as it was.

Back to top · My discography · Marathon soundtracks · Contact me · Website index

Endnotes

Endnotes
# Note
1. I spent unreasonably long trying to formulate a pun on Marcel Duchamp‚Äôs classic Modernist painting Nude Descending a Staircase, something along the lines of ‚ÄòLydian Descending a Scale‚Äô, but every phrasing I formulated ultimately felt too awkward, shoehorned, and/or unhelpful‚Ä¶ so I just created this not-at-all awkward, shoehorned, or unhelpful endnote instead.
2. Sanskrit: ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ó
3. Sanskrit: ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞; also sometimes romanized as swara
4. Sanskrit: ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø; also sometimes romanized as shruti
5. Thus, if you‚Äôve ever misspelled chord as cord (or vice versa⁽¹³⁾), you weren‚Äôt entirely wrong, especially since chord and cord both come from ·º° œáŒøœÅŒ¥ŒÆ (hē khordḗ) in ancient Greek. We can blame the French for the two senses being romanized differently, since they changed the Latin chorda to corde, which later reverted to chord for the musical sense. Of course, we can also blame the French for almost our entire language ‚Äì and if you think I‚Äôm joking, see my comparison of Beowulf and The Canterbury Tales.
6. It is worth recalling here that typical definitions of ‚ÄúAncient Greece‚Äù use timespans of no fewer than 750 years. The earliest possible end point is the Roman conquest in 31-30 BCE; the second Arab siege of Constantinople in 717-718 CE is the latest typical end date. Typical start dates are Ischia‚Äôs settlement in 785 BCE or Euboea‚Äôs rise ca. 1200 BCE ‚Äì already a possible span of nearly two millennia. However, it would be technically correct (the best kind of correct!) to start it with the rise of Aegean Greece ca. 3300 BCE, which passes two crucial tests: it was over five millennia ago (i.e., it was ancient), and its name includes ‚ÄúGreece‚Äù (i.e., it was Greek). Thus, the broadest possible view of the term encompasses over four millennia.
7. ⁽ᵃ⁾ ⁽ᵇ⁾ For instance, here‚Äôs the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy ⟨plato.stanford.edu/entries/archytas/#Mus⟩ on Archytas:
Archytas‚Äô final contribution to music theory has to do with the structure of the scale (for a more detailed account than what follows, see Huffman 2005: 402‚Äì25 and Barker 2007: 292‚Äì302). The Greeks used a number of different scales, which were distinguished by the way in which the fourth, or tetrachord, was constructed. These scales were grouped into three main types, or genera. One genus was called the diatonic; one example of this is the Pythagorean diatonic described above, which is built on the tetrachord with the intervals 9:8, 9:8, and 256:243, and was used by Philolaus and Plato. There is no doubt that Archytas knew of this diatonic scale, but his own diatonic tetrachord was somewhat different, being composed of the intervals 9:8, 8:7, and 28:27. Archytas also defined scales in the two other major genera, the enharmonic and chromatic. Archytas‚Äô enharmonic tetrachord is composed of the intervals 5:4, 36:35, and 28:27, and his chromatic tetrachord of the intervals 32:27, 243:224, and 28:27.

There are several puzzles about the tetrachords which Archytas adopts in each of the genera. First, why does Archytas reject the Pythagorean diatonic used by Philolaus and Plato? Second, Ptolemy, who is our major source for Archytas‚Äô tetrachords (A16), argues that Archytas adopted as a principle that all concordant intervals should correspond to superparticular ratios. The ratios in Archytas‚Äô diatonic and enharmonic tetrachords are indeed superparticular, but two of the ratios in his chromatic tetrachord are not superparticular (32:27 and 243:224). Why are these ratios not superparticular as well? Finally, Plato criticizes Pythagorean harmonics in the Republic for seeking numbers in heard harmonies rather than ascending to generalized problems (531c). Can any sense be made of this criticism in light of Archytas‚Äô tetrachords?

The basis for an answer to all of these questions is contained in the work of Winnington-Ingram (1932) and Barker (1989, 46‚Äì52). The crucial point is that Archytas‚Äô account of the tetrachords in each of the three genera can be shown to correspond to the musical practice of his day; Ptolemy‚Äôs criticisms miss the mark because of his ignorance of musical practice in Archytas‚Äô day, some 500 years before Ptolemy (Winnington-Ingram 1932, 207). Archytas is giving mathematical descriptions of scales actually in use; although mathematical considerations did play a role (Barker 2007: 295‚Äì302), he arrived at his numbers in part by observation of the way in which musicians tuned their instruments (Barker 1989, 50‚Äì51). He did not follow the Pythagorean diatonic scale because it did not correspond to any scale actually in use, although it does correspond to a method of tuning. The unusual numbers in Archytas‚Äô chromatic tetrachord do correspond to a chromatic scale in use in Archytas‚Äô day. Ptolemy was wrong to suggest that Archytas adhered to the principle that all concordant intervals should have superparticular ratios (Huffman 2005: 422‚Äì3), although Barker suggests that he may have been following a different but related principle (2007: 301).

Archytas thus provides a brilliant analysis of the music of his day, but it is precisely his focus on actual musical practice that draws Plato‚Äôs ire. Plato does not want him to focus on the music he hears about him (‚Äúheard harmonies‚Äù), but rather to ascend to consider quite abstract questions about which numbers are harmonious with which. Plato might well have welcomed a principle of concordance based solely on mathematical considerations, such as the principle that only superparticular ratios are concordant, but Archytas wanted to explain the numbers of the music he actually heard played. There is an important metaphysical issue at stake here. Plato is calling for the study of number in itself, apart from the sensible world, while Archytas, like Pythagoreans before him, envisages no split between a sensible and an intelligible world and is looking for the numbers which govern sensible things. For discussions of Archytas as the target of Plato‚Äôs complaints in the Republic, see Huffman 2005: 423‚Äì5 and Barker 2014: 192‚Äì3.

(I‚Äôve lightly edited the above text by removing spaces within ratios and adding commas and line breaks for legibility‚Äôs sake [the entire quote was originally a single paragraph!], but it is otherwise unchanged.)

I feel justified in concluding from this that Plato and Ptolemy, vastly more famous though they are, are very likely less reliable than Archytas where ancient Greek musical practice is concerned (even if much of our knowledge of Archytas‚Äô musical writings comes secondhand from Ptolemy).
8. We hates it, precious. We hates it forever.

The industry framing of ‚Äúpitch correction‚Äù is gaslighting at the most fundamental level. It‚Äôs pitch alteration or quantization; the correct pitch was what the singer sang live. Second-guessing professional singers at such an intrusive level is an incomprehensibly disrespectful practice that needs to die yesterday. Many of the world‚Äôs best living vocalists have been subjected to it, including Dimash Qudaibergen, David Draiman, and Yungblud, even in recordings of live performances. There‚Äôs absolutely no excuse for this.

In routinely ascribing powers to Auto-Tune and Melodyne that they don‚Äôt possess, many of their harshest critics are acting as more effective salespeople than their marketing staffs could ever have dreamt of. Pitch alteration doesn‚Äôt make bad singing into good singing. Indeed, it can‚Äôt. It alters exactly one thing: pitch. It doesn‚Äôt alter bad intonation, support, projection, breath control, phrasing, diction, or rhythm; bad singing with an altered pitch is just bad singing minus emotional honesty. As I explain elsewhere, I hate pitch alteration not for disguising bad singing, but for stripping it of texture and emotion, thus making it worse.

9.

My brain wants Chromatic Phrygian inverse to follow Chromatic Mixolydian. Instead of listing symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (which you can thank, alongside autism, for this entire page), it‚Äôs probably simpler to just tell readers to look at the following table‚Äôs interval columns.

Hypodorian A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠ 1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω
Dorian E‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ô≠A‚ôÆB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ô≠ ¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω

Mixolydian inverse F‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆ 11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Dorian inverse C‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆG‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω11¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω
Hypodorian inverse G‚ôÆA‚ôØB‚ôÆC‚ôÆD‚ôØE‚ôÆF‚ôÆ 1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1¬Ω¬Ω¬Ω1

Now my brain is screaming at me about the notes; it wants Chromatic Dorian inverse to follow Chromatic Mixolydian, again to preserve a pattern. OK, fine, brain, make up your mind.

My brain is now screaming in agony at me because I can‚Äôt make both patterns line up in the same table. As a result, I now have Words for two abstract parties:

  1. Dear brain,

    I know the diatonic genus‚Äô regularity has spoiled you. I know the other genera lack it, and I‚Äôm sorry, but please stop punishing me for it. I didn‚Äôt do it. It‚Äôs not my fault.

    Love,
    Aaron
  2. Dear mathematics,

    You are such a harsh mistress.

    Love,
    Aaron

On a serious note, these tables demonstrate another reason the ancient Greek diatonic genus became the basis of modern Western harmony. It possesses a regularity absent from every other seven-note scale. It‚Äôs predictable; it‚Äôs entirely based on the circle of fifths in a way none of the others are.
10. It‚Äôs called «ŒõŒøŒ∫œÅ·ø∂ŒΩ Œ∏œÅ·øÜŒΩŒøœÇ» [romanized: Lokrôn thr√™­nos], Ancient Greek for ‚ÄúLocrian Lament‚Äù, and appears on one of my recent albums, Compositions 2023-2024 ⟨aaronfreed.github.io/compositions2023-2024notes.html⟩. It also changes time signature every measure, from 1/8 in the first measure to 21/8 in the twenty-first, before the pattern repeats ‚Äì which is every bit as disorienting as this description probably leads you to expect it to be.
11. ‚ÄúHe who fights monsters should see to it that he himself does not become a monster; and if you gaze for long into an abyss, the abyss gazes also into you.‚Äù
‚ÄìFriedrich Nietzsche, Beyond Good and Evil Aphorism 146
12. The ‚ÄúShell‚Äù Transport and Trading Company imported and sold seashells. ‚ÄúSell oil‚Äù rhymes with one of its better-known later names: Shell Oil Company. This is no coincidence. Ren doesn‚Äôt do coincidences.
13. While I‚Äôm at it, the ancient Romans would‚Äôve pronounced vice versa as something like wee-keh wer-sah.
